messages.content:
You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

document:
  sections:
  - type: personalInformation
    order: 1
    content:
    - name: "Dzianis Shupenka"
      dateOfBirth: "03.02.1987"
      phoneNumber: "+375336911715"
      email: "dzianisshupenka@gmail.com"
      linkedin: "http://linkedin.com/in/dzianis-shupenka-b0a39093/"
      github: "http://github.com/dzianisshupenka"
      profile: "Junior frontend developer, React developer\nWeb developer, at the start of my way, looking for a company in which there will be an opportunity to grow as a very good specialist."
  - type: education
    order: 2
    content:
    - institution: "MGPK, Maladechna, Belarus"
      degree: "Electrician technician"
      dates: "09.2004 - 05.2007"
  - type: experience
    order: 3
    content:
    - organization: "Construction and assembly organizations"
      role: "Technical worker, builder"
      dates: "04.2009 - present"
      description: "The whole range of construction and electrical work"
    - organization: "Self-education"
      role: "Frontend developer, React developer"
      dates: "12.2019 - present"
      description: "Create React apps, SPA, functional components, class components, interactions between components, HOC, work with Context API, Fetch, Axios, Redux"
  - type: skills
    order: 4
    content:
    - skill: "HTML, CSS, JS - basic"
    - skill: "React, Redux, Context API, Hooks"
    - skill: "Figma, Zeplin, Adobe Photoshop - basic"
  - type: languages
    order: 5
    content:
    - language: "English - B1 Intermediate"
    - language: "Russian - Native"
  - type: personalityTraits
    order: 6
    content:
    - trait: "Self-learning"
    - trait: "Creativity"
    - trait: "Responsibility"
    - trait: "Organized"
  - type: software
    order: 7
    content:
    - software: "Figma - basic"
    - software: "Zeplin - basic"
    - software: "Adobe Photoshop - basic"
  - type: hobbies
    order: 8
    content:
    - hobby: "Technology"
    - hobby: "Music"
    - hobby: "Reading"
  additionalInformation:
  - type: disclaimer
    description: "I agree that my personal data will be processed in order to recruit for the position I am applying for."

It's a tough situation for a switcher, exacerbated by the lack of relevant experience and education. The advice would be more about gaining that relevant experience, I don’t know how. Maybe through freelancing, or courses with job placement, as your current experience is not substantial.
In my opinion, it's better to remove those 'basic' labels.
Also, you mention technology as an interest — perhaps you have some applied projects (like Raspberry Pi or Arduino) that would make your education shine in conjunction with software engineering.
Hello! The message format is quite "direct," but I didn't mean to offend or touch a nerve.

Starting with the main point, the primary goal for a beginner is to get an interview at all costs. Therefore, you need to remove anything that might "scare" HR away.

- Remove your birth date (if needed, they will ask). In frontend development (on average): …-22 for juniors, 22-25 for mid-levels, 26-… for seniors, etc. (that’s how it is in Ukraine). Essentially, you should be a senior, so it's better to hide this and quickly grow to the necessary level.

- The description needs to change: the company isn’t interested in an employee's growth; they just need money. Juniors are usually hired for tasks that nobody wants to do or if the company has a low budget (mostly the case in our regions). Imagine you have your own startup, you've received investments, and you need people: seniors for core tasks, mid-levels for those seniors, and maybe a couple of juniors for mundane jobs. What kind of junior would you hire? Look at your resume and answer: would you hire yourself? Your goal is to make it so that you confidently answer "yes." Business is not charity, so they look at you like this: can you bring in money or not (after a while since you are a junior)? Companies don't care what you want. Unfortunately, that's how it is. You are a product, and you need to persuade them to buy you.)

- From your work experience, remove the lines about self-education. It’s better to simply state freelancing (even though that’s already a cliché, so better to avoid that too). Write that you supported their website at the university, etc. Nowadays, there are plenty of jobs where you can work just for food (as a volunteer). Or find any professional developer who is working on a personal project and ask if you can help with it. You could find a struggling web studio in your city that does all sorts of PHP, Joomla, WordPress, etc. (I did that in my time).

- Remove all references to Figma, Zeplin, VS Code, etc.

- Remove references to Context API and hooks. That’s part of React, which you already added.

P.S. the first job is the hardest to get, and most beginners give up at this point. You just need to endure it. After that, things will be fine.)

document:
  sections:
  - type: education
    order: 1
    content:
    - institution: Higher School of Economics
      degree: Bachelor in Applied Mathematics and Information Science
      dates: Sep 2019 - Expected Jun 2023
      gpa: 9.18/10.0
    - institution: Samara Lyceum of Information Technology
      dates: Sep 2017 - Jun 2019
      accolades: Received a gold medal for academic excellence.
  - type: workExperience
    order: 2
    content:
    - position: Linear Algebra Teaching Assistant
      organization: Higher School of Economics
      dates: Sep 2020 - Jun 2021
      location: Moscow, Russia
    - position: Software Engineering Intern
      organization: Huawei
      dates: Jul 2020 - Sep 2020
      location: Moscow, Russia
      description: Ported an OS performance analysis system from Linux to Windows 10. Implemented a GUI for OS performance analysis tool using Python and Tcl/Tk.
    - position: Algorithms Teaching Assistant
      organization: Summer Informatics School
      dates: Aug 2019
      location: Laagna, Estonia
      description: Developed front-end for a sports website using HTML5, CSS3 and JavaScript.
    - position: Python Developer
      organization: SamExpress
      dates: Jun 2018 - Aug 2018
      location: Samara, Russia
      description: Developed and maintained some scrapers, including one that searches applications on a website and sends information about them on e-mail using Selenium and SMTP libraries. Developed a program which makes a raw Excel document readable using xrd, xlwt and xlutils libraries.
  - type: skills
    order: 3
    content:
    - codingLanguages:
      - C++
      - Python
      - C
      - Bash
    - technologies:
      - Git/GitHub/GitLab
      - Windows
      - Linux
    - languages:
      - native Russian
      - advanced English
      - beginner German
  - type: projects
    order: 4
    content:
    - title: Hash Map
      description: Implemented hash map with full functionality using separate chaining with linked list in C++.
    - title: External Sorting
      description: Implemented external sorting (the algorithms splits all input into blocks, sorts them separately, and then ends up with a sorted array by recursively merging K array’s segments) using C++.
  - type: academicAchievements
    order: 5
    content:
    - All-Russian Informatics Olympiad Awardee.
    - Winner of "Vyshaia Proba" Informatics Olympiad and all-Siberian Informatics Olympiad.
    - Master at Codeforces.
  - type: hobbies
    order: 6
    content:
    - description: Teaching school students algorithms and data structures individually.

Information about the school is not needed, language skills are not needed, hobbies are not needed.

The projects are not described very well, I would suggest finding some interesting projects to describe their impact better.
I would recommend keeping the hobby, but only one: "Teaching school students algorithms and data structures individually," as it is directly related to programming.

      dates: 'March 2020'
      responsibilities:
      - 'Communicated with a group of children and explained to them the basics of Python'
      - 'Involved children and youth in learning programming; increased their knowledge about technical tools, programming languages and opportunities for IT education'
      - 'Taught students to create their own programs and projects'
  - type: technicalSkills
    content:
    - skills:
      - 'Python (NLP, NLTK, JSON, plotly, matplotlib, PEP 8 standard of coding)'
      - 'C, Java, HTML, CSS'
      - 'Web Development (Flask, Dash, Pythonanywhere hosting)'
      - 'API knowledge, Git, PyCharm, VS Code, CLion, IntelliJ IDEA'
  - type: awardsAndActivities
    content:
    - 'Won a scholarship for tuition fees for Bachelor studies based on academic and leadership rewards'
    - 'Won in Synchro Space Hackathon with a project aimed to triple the use of bicycles on the island of Khortytsa in Ukraine'
    - 'Participated in ICPC (International Collegiate Programming Contest)'
    - 'Participated in University Parliament where working in a team and creating projects to improve the lives of students'
    - 'Volunteer at Lviv Regional Youth Center (July 2018 - Present) where organize social projects for young people, contribute to local and national forums and events'
    - 'Spoke on youth lectures about communication skills and opportunities in small cities'
    - 'Volunteered in an orphanage and in a home for the elderly'
    - 'Volunteered at Lviv IT Arena (September 2019), Book Forum Lviv (May 2018 and September 2018), Lviv Oratory Open (June 2018)'

It's unclear what position this resume is for. It will read differently for an intern and a developer.
I would remove it. The resume is in English, you can speak – there should be no problems. You can change "term work" to "coursework." In terms of content, it's quite impressive for a second-year student.
Try to diversify the resume by using and , otherwise, it's very hard to read such monotonous text; the eyes need to latch onto something specific.

Experience looks like Projects; if it is, then it’s worth renaming.

Also, add numbers: by how many percent?

The same for teaching: how many students did you teach, how many lessons did you give, how many students completed their projects?

It's not clear how Python is separated from the other languages. Given the listed libraries under Python and the absence in others, it seems you know only the syntax in other languages.

Awards and activities turned out too lengthy. One line for volunteering, numbers about participants in the hackathon. Participations aren’t very important.

Ideally, the largest part of the resume should be devoted to projects and explanations of why they are cool, especially if there's no work experience.

Also, Tylek Mamutov recommends a very good framework for proofreading your resume; it’s worth checking out and reevaluating your resume.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

I'm not a developer, in the sense that I've never hired developers in the team. But I'm familiar with the topic. Here's what catches the eye:
It's unclear what you want to do. Of course, these things can be tailored to a specific role, but for beginners, you're looking for either minimal experience with the stack used, or that they want it and are self-learning.

SQL language? Probably for queries, but listed after commas with others, it seems strange. Of course, recruiters are looking for SQL from you, and even if you don't fully understand the efficiency of operations and scaling, it just wants to be mentioned. Similarly, the tools for developers. If you don't want details, I'd only keep Docker and that as an environment or packaging. In your categories, there are so few words that I would either condense them or provide more detail. There’s a whole specialty for linters, it’s not about learning MD to write.
There’s nothing said about Go going forward. Who needs it besides Google, I'm not sure. In my opinion, C++ and Python are already great.

Libraries are specified and unspecified at the same time. I would just write specific names instead of "the majority of ML libraries". That is, in this line, there’s simply no useful info for anyone.
Regarding ML, there are heaps of libraries, and if I'm not mistaken, you should have a high-level understanding of why one library over another, and how to prepare and validate data. If you're not afraid of questions - specify.

Organization names might not be well-known to foreigners, but when you have to search for them in the text, that's not good.

Huawei suffers from formatting. I like it:)

Mentioning part-time work in the context of study seems strange. There’s a belief that what is done is more important than where it’s done.

When listing all your achievements at work, it’s better to try to bring them to XYZ (search "Google XYZ formula").

I'm not Amazon, but I don't see leadership. Perhaps the previous point will rectify this automatically.

Maybe I'm being picky, but I would write the entire year; there's plenty of space. It's like starting your career after 2012; can you blow people's minds?))
Cool👍
"Reproduced articles" sounds strange ("reproduce experiments" ... is normal).
"The work became a basis of my MSc thesis" - it's not clear what exactly that work was.
"Conduct" => "conducted"?
"Patched 3 opensource libraries" => if any are somewhat famous, which ones exactly?
"Prepared summaries for 4 meetings" sounds like secretary work, maybe "organized/led meetings"?

Oh wow

I want to rewrite the last job in style
* did this
* did that
* got praised
Yikes) In terms of style - remove all images, remove these stripes in skills - write properly.
The education mentioned in this way suggests that you didn't finish your studies, because usually a person gets some degree, indicates it and is proud, since it took a lot of effort and time.
Earlier it was already mentioned to remove images and skill bars. They don't show anything factual except that this person has communication skills, for example, more than knowledge of Apollo. And then the question is, how did this person even measure it? It's better to just list skills. And personally, I prefer not to indicate hobbies, it's better to replace them with something useful.
I think that for an entry-level position, you can briefly describe projects from GitHub directly in the resume, at least functionality and used technologies.
+ 

Also, I am very conservative regarding CV design and I think there should be more content than pictures. But maybe that's subjective.
A person measures it in exactly the same way as everyone else. Apple sends a questionnaire before an interview, where self-evaluation is needed. Well numerically, not with stripes. Why are you all picking on them?

Regarding education, it may be a valid point, but what difference does it make if they are still a lawyer, non-profile?
Tell me what's really important, let's leave nitpicking aside.
I always imagine that a skill bar at 100% for JS means you know the language at the level of an architect and creator of the language itself) so even 70% - that's already a lot!
No, no, it's fine here.
Let's get to the point

I'm an enthusiastic Frontend Developer seeking an
entry-level position at a company where I can use my
previous experience and skills in projects which push
me to develop in the software engineering field and
related spheres.

Blah blah blah. What kind of person is this? What experience do they have? How can they be useful? 5 lines of nothing. A copy-paste from the first page of a Google search "what to write at the beginning of a resume"
No questions about language proficiency.

Next, experience. Good experience! social responsibility - homeless people, kids, sports. All good.

My main responsibilities were
to develop new user-facing features, build stable
code, collaborate with back-end developers and web
designers to improve usability, write functional
requirement documents and guides, contribute to
daily scrum meetings, sprint reviews, and planning
sessions.

This isn't CIA torture, one could probably reveal what those user features were, what they collaborated on with the back-end, what the person contributed to during meetings and sprint reviews. There’s so much space - just describe it, don't hold back. Add links to projects. Point and say - I thought this up and embodied it.

Moreover, it’s clear that this person was hired right after the internship - that's good. They must have performed better than others - why not mention that? Again, there’s plenty of space, just remove the pizza.
This is just my opinion regarding the skill bars. They are useless and harmful. Because a person can't evaluate themselves normally, and to me, that doesn't look good.

Better to add numbers. This has been said many times, and people started adding, but the bars are still being shoved in.
100% in JavaScript means Brendan Eich himself :).
Well written, I generally agree.
In fact, I imagine a recruiter sitting there comparing. This candidate has 60%, and the other has 70%. Well, we're definitely taking the second one.
That's the point.
Once a recruiter asked to rate my Python skills on a 10-point scale without any criteria or scores given. I assumed 10 meant the level of Van Rossum and replied around 5. To which I heard: well, can it at least be a 6? The requirements state a minimum of 6/10.
- Steve Jobs
I need to respond, "Yes, it's me. Hello."
Even 50 percent is not bad, because 2 such people like you in a team is already Van Rossum!

PlayStation is written as one word.
Not a rating but just a reminder – Nikita is more often a female name in the USA.
Implemented game client - it’s not enough, describe more in simple terms so the reader understands the essence. And add a link; since it’s a Hackathon, there must be a website or something like that.
Leaded - Led.
Advice for the future: since you include your projects in the resume, they should be top-notch. I understand that the code might be bad (laziness to write, just to make it work and solve the problem – I experience that too), but documentation in README is a must, where to go if people will look at the project page on GitHub, they will definitely check that. It’s an example of caring for users and those who just stop by to see and understand what has been done.
Serious approach to documentation, I respect it.

One thing is when you list technologies next to your achievements. Like, I did this and that using this technology. That can make sense. But another thing is just to duplicate the list of technologies, which you already have in a separate section, next to the company name. What do you think about that?
It’s not quite clear in which countries/cities you studied or worked. Also, you could rephrase the achievements to convey the value and impact of your work; I would keep the languages, but possibly reformat them visually.
In the achievements, the eye catches a single digit, and that is 0 - don’t do that, it gives a bad impression :) Better to write from scratch. 

"Worked to optimize" - well, since it's optimization, there were probably some numbers, sped it up by x percent - you could write that.

"Logger and validation starter" - well, it’s like "Petya, instruments!", it doesn't make sense, it should either be expanded or removed. Overall, be more careful with the forms - if it’s past tense, then it should clearly be past tense, not sporadic work, support.

"Started to write code review for colleagues" - this "started" is unclear, if this is personally new experience for you, it's better to omit "started", if it's new experience for the team - on the contrary, emphasize it.

"Abiturents" - unknown creatures :)

Overall, I like the resume.

```
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

In my opinion, everything is great - you can send it to the Canadian SAP on Hybrid right now :) PS. The only small note, I would remove Part-Time and just keep Contract for that Chicago contract.
As soon as I saw Vladimir and Java, I immediately thought of FGBU "VNIIZH"👍
Will this not cause a series of questions, since the timelines overlap?

But they are contracts! :) In Canada and the UK, on the contrary, the tax authorities start asking questions if the dates don't overlap :).
Why even mention this job if the timelines overlap? It seems to me that this will raise more questions than give any advantage for the resume. I would only include this information on LinkedIn, not in the resume.

I currently have a full-time contract, I work as an individual entrepreneur. Nevertheless, this is different from freelance employment.
In this case, the contract overlaps not with another contract but with full-time employment.
I completely disagree. We're talking about contract work.

I believe that any American experience is valuable for the North American labor market. If I were hiring someone from abroad, the fact that they have successful work experience in the US would indicate their communication skills, language proficiency, and that the candidate is "mature". This is much stronger than two gigs on a resume.)

I do not understand what has changed because of this. I am working two jobs — one for 8 hours and the other for 4 hours. I need to create a resume. At the one where I work for 8 hours, I have a lot of achievements, while at the other it is fewer and lower quality, conditionally. In my example, I see no point in mentioning the second job at all.
I didn't even notice that. And I didn't understand what precisely you wanted to emphasize. It never even occurred to me that having contract experience with some foreign company would be a bonus. But since you think so, that is important.
That is my logic, but I am posting it for review to hear all opinions and form a clear picture 🙂

Of course, it is a bonus. :) Try to get such a contract from our respected American or British partners yourself, your opinion will change immediately :). In terms of <live> money in Canada/UK, contract work exceeds the blessed and desirable FAANG (for the appropriate level) :).

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Do you speak French? Are you looking for a job in Canada?
It seems that these North American templates let us down in the education section. Their universities are well-known in the local market, so it makes sense to highlight your alma mater. 

Why bold that you graduated from Novosibirsk State University, but list your degree in small gray font? 

You have a master’s directly in your field and you obtained it just 2 years ago. This should be placed at the very beginning, so they notice that you have 2 master’s degrees in a pretty cool field, not to mention that both were obtained not in your native language :) 

I would place education much higher, highlight degrees and thesis titles.

Also - you were taken as an intern in Belgium (is this an online job?) and kept on after graduation. This is indicative as well. They liked you. 

Regarding formatting - the fonts are inconsistent and you have enough whitespace to not make responsibilities small.
Hmm, it seems like the LinkedIn link is a bit off. It should be 
* 
* but in the PDF, it seems like 
that is, /in/ got lost.

B1, I decided not to include it since I don't feel comfortable speaking it.
Oh, thank you for being so detailed!
The internship was offline; it was necessary to complete my French university.
Oh, yes, I didn't notice, thank you.

It's not about that. If you're looking for a job in Canada, then Francophones don't need to do an LMIA, and if you have a job offer, you can apply for a work visa by simply attaching exam results, even if your work won't be related to the French language.

But B1, of course, is too little. At least B2.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

For regular languages, specify the level like C1 - advanced, B2 - upper-intermediate, etc.
3rd grade student means a third-grader. You are a 3rd year bachelor student.

This is my first comment here, but I was taught that in the experience description, there should be action verbs (performed, prepared, created, made, improved, etc.) and after the action verb, there should be some quantitative characteristics; simply saying 'huge' is not appropriate, that’s subjective.
I have purely formal objections - everything gray is too much. Headings should be made black or close to black, and the rest of the text darker; otherwise it looks very dull and merges.
Instead of 'finished', it’s better to write 'graduated', and 'used to learning English' should be 'used to study English'. Overall, excellent. Maybe add how you learned programming.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

        fontSize: 12
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: "#000000"

        fontFamily: Arial
        fontSize: 12
        fontWeight: normal

        fontFamily: Arial
        fontSize: 12

      - text: "Redesigned the web application using HTML5 and CSS3. Added a responsive layout that made it possible for users to use the application from mobile devices."
        fontFamily: Arial
        fontSize: 12
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: "#000000"

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

It's called a lastname for a reason

And implemented Otbasy bank application - I need to think about this more.

Developed and launched online services which helped reduce the load on the Bank's branches - can you be any less specific?
Branches of the bank is default. You don't need to specify.

Counseled the company's contractor. - It says that you consulted some high-ranking contractor of the company that everyone knows.

Integrated analytics and metrics. - You can write why and for whom, to be at least a little more specific.

I have communicated directly with a business unit also collected and analyzed business requirements. - Usually no one writes "I have".

Reduced the process of opening Bank's products from 3 days to 5 minutes. - There are more questions than answers here. What does opening mean?

The rest is okay, interesting.

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.

Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Passed 4 qualifying s, I didn't understand this.
Typo: number thory, presctigious, olympiade
It's better to do education in reverse chronological order. Plus, maybe translate the grades into a normal GPA. It's not usually measured on a 5-point scale. 

Regarding the Olympiads: yes, it's not very clear what 4 stages mean. Being in the top alone is enough. 

Your projects are very good; I would place them right after education. But that's a personal preference. 

You mentioned that you know both C and C++. But I didn't see any projects with them. How come?
Maybe elevate the university to the education section.
Perhaps find a synonym.
Hi, regarding the last point, I have a related question (want to understand): if I have group coursework in frontend web, which I am shy about and likely won't put in my CV, should I also not display the technologies used there in my skills? 

It seems fine since if they ask for proof of using those skills, it would only be verbal, but isn't it better than not indicating them at all?

P.S. This is applicable to intern and new graduate.

Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

document:
  sections:
  - type: experience
    order: 1
    content:
    - company: "FARO Europe GmbH"
      role: "Software Developer"
      location: "Stuttgart, Germany"
      dates: "Oct. 2020 - now"
      accomplishments:
      - "Built the backend part of a web application that uses object detection to assist users with counting objects in images, decreasing the time it takes to write bills in construction firms by the factor of 10 for a subset of objects."
      - "Developed a replacement for an existing object detection visualization canvas that conveyed center points instead of bounding boxes, reducing time spent by user on feedback to 1s per object and making the visualization of counted objects easier to understand."
      - "Extended an opensource panoramic image conversion library with company-specific coordinate transformations, extraction of 3D points from 2D polygon with corresponding distance maps and polygon conversion between equidirectional and rectilinear coordinates."
      - "Written CI/CD pipelines for automatic unit and integration testing, building and releasing of Docker images and Python packages."
      - "Created datasets and trained object detection models for counting pipe elements in construction sites achieving 48 mAP on 4 object classes."
      - "Introduced model and dataset versioning and tracking to the team, achieving reproducibility of training runs."
    - company: "HELLA Aglaia Mobile Vision GmbH"
      role: "Working Student"
      location: "Berlin, Germany"
      dates: "Aug. 2019 - July 2020"
      accomplishments:
      - "Wrote a data processing pipeline that extracted a demosaicing dataset from 1 Petabyte of raw camera data."
      - "Used ffmpeg to compress 4 Terabytes of data to evaluate the effect of compression on deep learning algorithms."
      - "Analyzed hardware constraints and developed a network architecture for demosaicing with 7ms/Mpix inference time on an embedded chip."
      - "Implemented and trained demosaicing models, evaluating results for perceptual quality against traditional demosaicing methods."
    - company: "A Model Scouting Startup"
      role: "Software Developer"
      location: "Berlin, Germany"
      dates: "Feb. 2018 - Sep. 2018"
      accomplishments:
      - "Fine-tuned face recognition models for face \"modelness\" classification, achieving 0.6 PR AUC on a heavily imbalanced and noisy dataset. Used pre-trained face recognition models to filter out profiles with celebrity photos."
      - "Implemented social media profile scrapers that filtered profile pictures using deep learning and stored profiles of interest in a database."
      - "Developed a desktop application that presented results of the scraping to the user, saved user feedback and controlled scrapers."
    - company: "RBO Lab, Technical University of Berlin"
      role: "Student Research Assistant"
      location: "Berlin, Germany"
      dates: "May 2018 - Apr. 2019"
      accomplishments:
      - "Implemented motion planning algorithms for stationary manipulators."
  - type: projects
    order: 2
    content:
    - title: "Autonomous RC Car"
      field: "Deep Learning, Computer Vision, Embedded Programming, Robotics"
      location: "Berlin, Germany"
      dates: "Feb. 2019 - Nov. 2019"
      description: "Collected and labeled a lane segmentation dataset, trained a lane segmentation model and converted it for on the edge inference. Developed an algorithm for steering based on lane segmentation results and integrated lane segmentation and steering with camera and actuators of the car, achieving 18 ms from camera image to steering decision."
  - type: education
    order: 3
    content:

      degree: "B.Sc. in Computer Science"
      location: "Berlin, Germany"
      dates: "Oct. 2016 - Nov. 2020"
      additionalInformation:
      - "Average grade 1.1 (GPA 3.9/4.0)."
  - type: skills
    order: 4
    content:
    - programmingLanguages:
      - language: "Python"
        proficiency: "proficient"
      - language: "C++"
        proficiency: "familiar"
      - language: "Javascript"
        proficiency: "C"
      - language: "Java"
        proficiency: "Scala"
      - language: "Haskell"
        proficiency: "episodic experience"
    - backendEngineering:
      - tools: "FastAPI, SQLAlchemy, TortoiseORM, SQL, Docker, docker-compose, Azure Devops Pipelines"
    - cloud:
      - services: "AWS EC2, S3, RDS, SOS, ECR, CodeArtifact"
    - machineLearningAndDataAnalysis:
      - libraries: "TensorFlow, Keras, Pytorch, Detector2, pandas, sklearn, XGBoost, MLFlow, DVC"
      - tasks: "Classification, segmentation, object detection, density estimation, compression, demosaicing"
    - deepLearningInferenceToolkits:
      - tools: "TorchServe, TFLite, Intel OpenVINO, TI TIDL"
    - hardware:
      - platforms: "Raspberry Pi, Google EdgeTPU, TI TD4A, Intel NCS 2"
    - other:
      - tools: "Eigen, ROS, Qt, Linux"

      - proficiency: "English (advanced), German (upper intermediate), Russian (native)"

A good template, very well described experience, with numbers, contributions, and efficiency indicators. In my opinion, a technical resume should be like this - without unnecessary distracting information, icons, and all that. Recruiters have seen so many resumes in their lifetime that impressive designs or pictures are unlikely to impress them. A recommendation, in the words of a blogger. But this is purely my view, as they say, to each their own.

A good template, very well described experience, with numbers, contributions, and efficiency indicators. In my opinion, a technical resume should be like this - without unnecessary distracting information, icons, and all that. Recruiters have seen so many resumes in their lifetime that impressive designs or pictures are unlikely to impress them. However, if the information is difficult to find, it will only frustrate them more. This resume clearly presents everything, has a clear structure, and emphasizes achievements. A recommendation, in the words of a blogger. But this is purely my view, as they say, to each their own.
Thank you for such positive feedback 🙂

Yes, that's right, the template is good, without flashy distracting icons. When recruiters sift through tons of text every day, factors like wild infographics a) irritate them and b) imply that the candidate doesn't understand the work of others, and thus isn't a team player.

It’s better to write dates in the style of Aug. 2017 - Sep. 2018, otherwise, they are hard to read. 
We want a bit more achievements, or to expand the existing ones. For example, "Have done code reviews." – most likely everyone did this to some extent, if you include such an item, write what results were achieved, what improved? Or "Prepared learning materials and runbooks to streamline the new-hire onboarding process." – how did the process improve as a result?
You might consider adding a dividing line to separate sections like EXPERIENCE, EDUCATION, etc. (like an underline across the entire width of the page), it feels a bit merged to me.

      company: Noveo

      responsibilities:
      - "Designed and implemented Single Page Application service that helped to visualize data collected from floating buoy on the ocean with sensors to the map."

There is no position you are applying for, and there is no list of technologies (even if there weren't any, I would expect to see them at least in the experience description, but they are not there either). I understand that you are kind of an engineer and can write on anything, but usually, the job market doesn't work that way, and it's better to add than not add, in my opinion.
And if you are going to look for a job now, I would combine the last two experiences at Yandex into one; it would look better. Especially against the background of your last job which you started only in October.
And the work period dates differ from those on LinkedIn—it would be good to align them.
I would make the links darker. "Acquired" and "acquisition" for some reason look like links. The 6 points all start with the word "Designed". This stands out. I would check the English very carefully because, for example, "Achieved scalability and bug rates" sounds strange. "Achieved security and scalability" is in the same category.

      - "Joined the team at an early stage of a startup and was responsible for developing all backend for mobile app, including cloud infrastructure and feature development, which leads to successful acquisition by Yandex."
      - "Designed and developed cloud infrastructure from scratch using ansible and docker containers, that helped us to remove vendor lock-in and saved 30% of expenses for servers"
      - "Proposed and implemented microservices architecture that increased security and scalability and reduced release time up to 50%"
      - "Designed a new data schema between mobile app and backend that reduced the mobile loading time up to 70%"
      - "Designed and developed new coupon section from scratch that increased total app revenue by 50%"
    - position: Software engineer
      company: Arello Mobile
      dates: Feb 2016 - Feb 2017
      location: Novosibirsk, Russia
      responsibilities:
      - "Integrated TDD into the development process that reduced the number of regression bugs by 50%"
      - "Designed and developed an app for Australian fire safety inspection company, backend and frontend"
      - "Proposed and implemented a database schema improvements that leads to 50% decrease response time from database"
    - position: Software engineer
      company: Noveo
      dates: Feb 2014 - Feb 2016
      location: Novosibirsk, Russia
      responsibilities:
      - "Designed and implemented Single Page Application service that helped to visualize data collected from floating buoy on the ocean with sensors to the map."
      - "Achieved security and scalability by containerizing app services into Docker containers."
      - "Achieved scalability and bug rates by initiating the movement from monolithic architecture to two-tier architecture."

There is no position you are applying for, and there is no list of technologies (even if there weren't any, I would expect to see them at least in the experience description, but they are not there either). I understand that you are kind of an engineer and can write on anything, but usually, the job market doesn't work that way, and it's better to add than not add, in my opinion.
And if you are going to look for a job now, I would combine the last two experiences at Yandex into one; it would look better. Especially against the background of your last job which you started only in October.
And the work period dates differ from those on LinkedIn—it would be good to align them.
I would make the links darker. "Acquired" and "acquisition" for some reason look like links. The 6 points all start with the word "Designed". This stands out. I would check the English very carefully because, for example, "Achieved scalability and bug rates" sounds strange. "Achieved security and scalability" is in the same category.

Yes, I also thought about that, thank you!
It would be a shame to burn out on this ) So how is work experience in a company generally proven? You can't show our labor in the USA.
I actually placed links to news about the acquisition, or is it not worth doing?

They will either call, send requests, or somehow use the tax authorities, I suppose. I can't help, I don't know, sorry.
Usually, it's confirmed through references. At the end of your resume, you can indicate "references available upon request." When they hire you, they will ask for contacts from your work, then call and verify a couple of your last workplaces. Another question is how they will do this in the CIS. You might try to preemptively get a letter from the HR department saying "Worked from _ to _, in position__", translate it into English, and provide it as reference letter during hiring.
No, I'm sorry; it was just that none of them were clickable for me, and I thought they weren't links. As it turned out, none of them can be clicked (I was in PDF selection mode). Regarding whether to place links to news, I think it's quite fine.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

software engineer with 5 years experience in the IT field.

And the other software engineers are not in IT?
IT is a system admin in English. What we call IT in Russian is called Tech in English.
1. In the section AT PROSCOM, "Design" (the "ed" is missing) and "developed"

3. Skills - I would not combine English and tech stacks together.
Thank you, where would it be better to place it?

You can split it into key technical skills and language skills (add Russian there as well)

Also, add city and country so that the recruiter knows where to relocate you if necessary.

And this is not quick, and I need money.

document:
  additionalInformation:
  - type: icon
    description: logo for Redmadrobot
  sections:
  - type: personalInformation
    order: 1
    content:
    - name: Petr Kozlov
      email: xd720p@gmail.com
      linkedin: petr-kozlov-69758bb0
      title: Android developer
  - type: technicalExperience
    order: 2
    content:
    - project: AlphaStrakhovanie
      role: Android Developer at Redmadrobot LLC (transferring to Mission:Luna company)
      dates: NOV 2018 - Present
      accomplishments:
      - Refactored code from old architecture based on inheritance to the new one with composition and taught myself RxJava 2 to replace similar legacy company-local libraries. These changes boosted development process with saving up to 20-30% of time.
      - Implemented new data syncing approach by dividing data into necessary one for the whole app and one that is needed for corresponding screens only. As the result app loading time was reduced from 10 to 2 seconds.
      - Developed a support chat using Webim SDK in tight deadlines collaborating directly with the customer and defining scope of features according to technical restrictions. Delivered this feature to users before the old solution stopped working.
    - project: Schoolkid
      role: Android Developer
      accomplishments:
      - Built a new project from scratch with new technology stack. Taught myself MVVM, Kotlin Flow and Android Navigation and led small team of 2 more android developers. Combining duties of tech lead and developer released an app within strict deadlines.
    - project: Toyota
      role: Android Developer
      accomplishments:
      - Cooperated with an international team in multi modular project and implemented maps for Russian market using Wanda MapKit which resulted in providing more accurate and relevant map for users of Toyota App.
    - project: Open source
      role: Contributor
      accomplishments:
      - Contributed in PhotoView library and fixed a bug of flipping image which had been bringing in 100% cases and decreased its occurrence to 0.
    - project: Binomo LLC
      role: Android Developer
      dates: JUL 2017 - NOV 2018
      accomplishments:
      - Redeveloped data syncing from "load everything on the start" to "load only necessary for screen logic" thus enhanced application loading time from 1 minute to 5-10 seconds and added an ability to restore app state properly after connection loss.
      - Migrated from Java to Kotlin using idiomatic Kotlin-style null-safety which increased crash-free sessions from 88% to 97%.
    - project: Chugun Partnership
      role: Junior Android Developer
      dates: SEP 2016 - JUL 2017
      accomplishments:
      - Having only academic experience in android released first MVP application in three months while studying Android SDK on-the-fly with following up developing of new features and fixing fatal and minor bugs.
  - type: education
    order: 3
    content:
    - degree: Master Degree in Computer Science
      institution: Saint-Petersburg Electrotechnical University "LETI"
      years: 2016 - 2018
    - degree: Bachelor Degree in Computer Science
      institution: Saint-Petersburg Electrotechnical University "LETI"
      years: 2012 - 2016
  - type: skills
    order: 4
    content:
    - languages:
      - Java
      - Kotlin
    - librariesAndFrameworks:
      - Android SDK
      - MVP Moxy
      - Google MVVM
      - Toothpick
      - Hilt
      - Cicerone
      - Android Navigation
      - RxJava 2
      - Kotlin Coroutines
      - Kotlin Flow
    - communication:
      - English(C1; IELTS 8.0)
      - Russian(native)
  - type: activities
    order: 5
    content:
    - year: 2020
      accomplishment: Became a program committee member of the Mobius conference(the biggest mobile development conference in Russia). Assessed participants from all over the world with their presentations, helped them to perfect it and make it more interesting and useful for the audience of mobile developers.
    - year: 2019
      accomplishment: Started from presentations about mobile development for our team and made it to tech conferences as a spokesperson. Made a presentation about DiffUtil under the hood on Saint-Petersburg AppsConf and DevFest and Novosibirsk DevFest with hundreds of viewers on each conference.

I think it would be better to move RxJava 2 to the next line in skills, and of course, Saint Petersburg should be separated.
Last part: OTHER PROFESSIONAL ACTIVITIES: Served on the program committee ...... Reviewed and selected papers from X international participants...
2019
• Started .... It's unclear. Just give the title of your report and the name of the conference; "under the hood" means hood as in a car hood or a cap. The number of people who listened to the report is not needed; that won’t impress anyone.

Hi) Read the resume tips - there’s a lot of useful information that will help enhance your resume (especially the sections about two columns and how to describe your experience and achievements, because experience is described, but achievements are not, even though it’s clear you have the potential for achievements from your experience).

From myself (besides what’s in the resume tips):
- I wouldn’t list the tech stack for each project when you already have a general list in Skills.
- It might be a bit more readable if you write related technologies within Skills next to each other. For example, Java, Kotlin, Coroutines Flow, RxJava (the order is slightly off right now).
- The grouping in Skills bothers me. Java, RxJava, Kotlin, KMM do not specifically relate to Android. I would move them to Programming Languages, especially considering KMM can be used for shared logic between Android and iOS. A separate testing point is a great experience)
- Tools can also be dropped because, with your experience, it's unlikely they'll check if you used Git.
- It’s better to reduce the amount of information while increasing the font size. I faced this on my resume - it became many times more readable when I raised it from 10pt to 11pt, while reducing the amount of information and removing the unnecessary.
- The methodologies you’ve worked with can be omitted right away. In a programmer’s resume, this looks unnecessary.
- The experience at Gamma Technologies isn't clear when you say "worked with three messengers": did you develop three messengers? Did you communicate in three messengers? Did you work with the teams of these messengers to write your own?
To be honest, the work experience is difficult to read. 
I think it would be better to use bold font and increase the size for the company names.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Easily. If the goal isn't just recruitment, but rather data collection or formalities. Or if the market has a surplus of candidates, then you can sift through them in bulk.
You can replace "Trainee" with "Intern" in the header, as usually interns are referred to as "Interns."
Irrelevant experience should be removed. Address, especially if remote, shouldn't be specified. The summary reads more like an essay and might be suitable for a cover letter; I don't have experience with that. What market are you targeting? If it's the CIS, write more about your experience and expertise there. If it's for the West, I don't know, maybe someone can tell you what's standard, but logically there should be a highlight of your professional profile.

Thank you!
Thank you) I'm targeting the West, I've just finished my courses before the war in Ukraine and don't have relevant experience.

Your previous experience may be beneficial for job searching, so you can still extract something from it in light of the new profession.
Include courses and similar qualifications if there is no experience. Generally, think for yourself if your past experience relates to the QA profession; if yes, include it, otherwise what's the point? Just to show that you worked before? It's quite normal not to have experience at the beginning of a career.
Thank you 🙏

It might be normal, but who needs you without experience?)
Courses can't be toxic, essentially worsening the chances of a resume, right? Like skill-box courses.
Whether without or with experience—say of a truck driver—these are two equivalent positions. That's my point. No matter how many years you worked in a field unrelated to IT, it won't make a difference.
I don't know; I can't imagine someone saying your courses are trash, so we won't hire you. Especially for that to happen often; it could be a unique case.
I understand, they probably won't say it to your face, but they might filter out such resumes right away.
HR might do that; I don't really know how they operate, but I've never heard of it. Regarding tech specialists, I can't imagine it; it's like you might not be liked due to your name or age. But maybe if the courses are all you have, it could influence decisions, like indicating poor education, so they won't even look. Maybe it's different in the Western market. My experience is that local tech specialists don't really know about courses and which ones are bad, at least that's my impression based on myself; I don't know of any courses.
These courses produce so many bad candidates that I think it's impossible not to know about the bad reputation of such courses.
Regarding not being liked due to age, that's pretty common; according to the latest survey from dou, the median age is around 27-29 years.
Imagine, I don't know of any courses, especially bad ones. That's the context in Ukraine. I'd value individual assessments more; you can end up in a bad company or attend bad courses; that doesn't determine whether the person is fit for the open position.
Yes, that's incorrect, but it happens. If you frequently attend interviews, you can even learn to notice when the interviewer is having a bad day))) And the result depends on that, too. So here, you can't predict.)

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Just without offense) I also wrote.
15+ projects in different areas  -> 15+ projects in different domains. In the West, it's "fashionable" to say "domains."
Resumes with one column parse better and are easier to read.
Hello! There's a lot of text and it's hard to catch anything with the eye (the problem of the template, the lack of proper indentations on the page also hinders). It's not very clear what the candidate was responsible for in the companies/projects. There's more information about the company than necessary -- it would be better to describe it in one sentence.
What about spheres?
As for the project interviews with EU/US clients - they often refer to "domains". At first, I didn't understand what they meant, but then I talked with recruiters who are oriented towards the West, and it became clear what they meant) I'm not saying this is the truth, it's just my experience.
Got it, thanks.

yes
I will warn you right away that all links in the original are hyperlinks, I don’t know why they are not clickable in Telegram.

Well, not a bad CV, but there are a few contentious points.
For example:
Why did you color the background under your name? It attracts attention, and in those 7 seconds, you definitely don’t want people to spend time on your name :)
And also, I hope you know that if you color the text through the preview, it still gets highlighted and I can see your email and phone number.

So, moving on. I’ll say right away that it’s good, but you want me to be tougher with you, right? ))

(ERC-721, ERC-20, Curve-AMM) - mentioning niche terminology is bad form
And also, there are 5 points about working on the ecosystem. And it seems everything makes sense, but honestly I didn’t understand exactly what you did. Okay, as a lead - you oversee people. I also didn’t understand what your responsibilities were and what project it was.

"Participated in multiple business critical projects as a part of an efficient, agile team" - too vague, not clear which kind of projects
"that was originated as a hackathon project" - why does the origin as a hackathon matter to me?
"Quickly embraced a technology stack of Ruby on Rails and React with TypeScript" - this statement feels weird to me. Not sure why. But I would have removed it. What does quickly mean? Is 1 day quick? Is 1 month quick?
"Led a team of fellow interns to complete a substantial project" - leading a team of interns while being an intern always raises more questions than it brings benefits. Why didn’t the company assign senior people to lead the whole group? Wasn’t anyone available? If so, then how can we know that your internship provided good mentoring if senior people are not assigned to lead projects but fellow interns are? Was this whole internship a waste of time where you just went to the office and did whatever you wanted? 


That’s about it.
But like I said, I was hard on it. Everything is fine with your CV

Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.

```
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Yulia, hello! A very well-written resume, kudos.  

A couple of notes:  
1. In the achievement descriptions, you could simplify the sentences. For example, "...with waiting for loan decision time decrease by 35%" -> "... and decreased decision time by 35%"  
2. The phrase "with 1+ year of experience" could probably be replaced: too many people include course completion in their experience. I think "with one year of commercial development experience" would be both true and sound more confident.  
3. If you had any interesting and +/- relevant experience before becoming a programmer, it would be interesting to see it.  

Good luck!
Very good resume. I would improve the education section. Bachelor of...  

You have React listed in the Frameworks section, but React is a Library.

Hello! 
It looks like a good resume! I would pay attention to a few things:
1) The second point in Renaissance: there's a strange repetition of "Accident, Property, and Travel" at the beginning and the end of the sentence, I think at the end it can be replaced with "... on these products"
2) The point about "Implemented URL-shortener" I would move to the very bottom, or add a description of how it helped improve metrics and which ones (the other points with numbers look more impressive in my opinion)
3) In the point "Reduced time of API response" I would rephrase "from 350 ms to 200ms max" to "decreased TTFB time by 175% to 200ms max..."
4) In the point "Led a 3-member team...", it seems to make sense to clarify what is meant by "productivity" and maybe mention what specific process improvements were made.
5) In the point "Implemented process-based architecture design" I didn't quite understand what units are being referred to at the end "10-20", is it percentages?

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Apparently things are really bad, since no one is criticizing)) Can you take a look and give feedback? I am currently aiming for Austria, Germany, and all Germanic countries...

Overall, it's a good resume, the design is fine and the content too

My notes:
- All points should start with action verbs; deploying, configuring, etc. won't work, even if this is your current job.
- A small note, but all periods at the beginning of sentences should be removed
- There are grammar issues. You need to check tenses and the overall structure of the sentences. For example, "deployed applications (…) and conducted training for 1000 employees". In general, it’s better to run it through a native speaker.
- My personal opinion, but I would combine the different positions within the company and only leave the highest position, and combine the bullet points. This will free up space and allow you to add, for example, projects
- It’s better to align the skills left so that they don't cross the right boundary. Or present them differently altogether
- Education should be at the top, preferably instead of the summary, although I get scolded for this here.
The DACH region loves resumes with photos. It's called "Lebenslauf."
Isn’t it better not to use -ING, but with done? It seems to look better when something is completed rather than being done.
I already said -ING won't work)

Hello. I'm a frontend developer, and in my opinion, the first thing that stands out is that after the A2 language level, you mention that you learn from movies, listen to songs, etc. I'd just leave the level as is, just A2. That's my opinion, and I'm interested in hearing what others, who are more knowledgeable than me, think.
I thought that YouTube education was a joke, but it's not :(

Half of the text can be safely deleted. No one is interested in how you learn English and what your interests are. This resume is a brief overview of professional achievements, not a questionnaire for a country club.
I'm interested in your opinion too. Thank you. If you have any more comments, don't hesitate. I can take it, I have brains (hopefully).

What is the goal of the resume? Which market are you aiming for?
In my opinion: just the English level is enough. How it's achieved is of little interest to anyone. Moreover, A2 is insufficient for communication in an English-speaking team. It's fine for reading documentation.
Questions and suggestions:
1. 04.2022 - 06.2022 - how did you go into the future?
2. In Postman, did you use the mock server? If yes, you can add that.
3. SQL - it's unnecessary to list a set of keywords. You can simply say "SQL - at the level of basic queries." Also, list the DBMS you've worked with - MS SQL, Postgres, etc.
4. For Android - "collecting" - does that mean you don't write code, but assemble someone else's?
5. It would be good to provide a list of the technologies/stack used. After reading the text, I have the impression that you kind of know HTML/CSS, JS, maybe even Java.

Regarding 1 = that's a contract. 
Regarding 4 = creating an apk file. 
I've noted the other points.

I've also just noticed that there are links in the resume text to Ilya Ivanov's GitHub. But this is Ilya Zakharov's resume.
1. If the resumes are printed for viewing with a bunch of others, the links will get lost.
If you want, you can indicate them in a separate section.
2. The last names don't match - there may be questions about whether it's yours.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

      - text: Worked on improving Qt WebEngine module – chromium embedding within Qt/QML APIs.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'

          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Ensured flawless functioning of module’s runtime in its key use cases – on small low power devices with touch screen for automation/automotive field and for full featured open source desktop browser implementations.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Implemented multiple new Qt/QML APIs for module: Web Notification, Certificate handling, Loading state, etc.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Streamlined C++ and QML API implementations within critical transition away from Qt 5.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Addressed accumulated API design issues, which significantly decreased maintenance burden for the next generation WebEngine in Qt 6.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Engaged with customers for in-depth issue analysis and technically consulted on using Qt framework efficiently.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Closely cooperated with open-source maintainers of web browsers on top of WebEngine (quebrowser, Falkon).
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Mentored junior teammates, gave guidance in coding and code review for newcomers and external contributors.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
    - title: Software Engineer
      company: STC
      website: www.stc-spb.ru
      location: Saint-Petersburg, Russia
      duration: May 2014 - March 2018
      responsibilities:
      - text: Designed transport layer framework atop CORBA technology for distributed processing of radio signals.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Integrated multiple internal projects from other teams within framework pipeline, which allowed to go from offline to realtime data processing, and also to increase throughput x1000 by scaling horizontally.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Developed GUI control program with custom visualizations for managing remote components within data pipeline, which eventually led to introduction of a new product with 20+ new business contracts.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Implemented CI/CD workflow and set up infrastructure for it. Introduced integration testing for the project.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Mentored 4 developers and support engineers by planning work, giving guidance in implementation and learning.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
    - title: Software Engineer
      company: Elecard-med
      website: www.em70.ru
      location: Tomsk, Russia
      duration: March 2011 - April 2014
      responsibilities:
      - text: Performed requirements gathering, implementation and testing of new GUI modules and database structures within existing medical system to assist doctors in keeping electronic medical history.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Optimized database and data flows to allow automatic report generation in medical facilities without human resources to be in compliance with local laws for reporting and accounting medical information.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Implemented CI. Ported the app for Linux to cut costs in 2 public hospitals by using open source environment.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
      - text: Designed and implemented abstraction layer and GUI framework for seamless program functioning in autonomous mode without connection to database.
        font:
          family: Arial
          size: 12
          weight: normal
          color: '#000000'
