        size: 12
        weight: normal
        color: #000000
        decorations: []

You need to unify all work experience in the Past Simple tense, stating what you did (you have present tense and -ing forms). It’s hard to get through the point about your approach. If you improved something by 90%, you don't need to say "greatly"; the numbers speak for themselves. A good construction is: "did X, which reduced/led to/increased..." I recommend including this where possible.
I wouldn't hesitate to write it like this for EPAM and other bodyshops (replace it with your account)

UBS Group AG 
Software Engineer. Kyiv, UA, Nov. 2016 - May 2017. EPAM Systems development for UBS. 

"• Led the design and implementation of architectural solutions that streamlined the deployment process for new services"; I suspect there was some interesting service there. It makes sense to first mention what the service is and why it’s so cool, and only then list the achievements made for it.
I would do the following:
1. Summary, Experience, Technical Skills, Education. Arrange them in order of importance descending.
2. In the work experience section, I would move the position up and the company name down.
3. The LinkedIn link is broken.
Yes, at some point, it becomes hard to read/utter for a recruiter who is not from the CIS. Maybe use an alias? For instance, Misha.
Also, I would play around with the university name; for people not from the CIS, it looks like a jumbled set of letters.
Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute or National Technical University of Ukraine
KPI uses both names as abbreviations in English.

Thank you. I experimented a lot with resume analyzers and Grammarly, so it turned out this way.
Then we also need to add projects where necessary.
Thank you for the feedback. I usually use Mikeyl when talking to foreigners. Regarding the university, it's more complicated here since there's an official form: full and abbreviated approved by the university itself.

Yes, at some point, your eyes get used to it. I used to insert the text into text-to-speech software; when you hear your text, all the flaws pop out immediately.
Yes, you can write different accounts, even if you have always been at EPAM, like

UBS Group AG 
Software Engineer. Kyiv, UA, Nov. 2016 - May 2017. EPAM Systems development for UBS. 

Apple
Software Engineer. Kyiv, UA, Nov. 2016 - May 2017. EPAM Systems development for Apple. 

Google
Software Engineer. Kyiv, UA, Nov. 2016 - May 2017. EPAM Systems development for Google. 

It’s good if the durations of the projects are a year or more.
And technologies should be added to the projects. Recruiters often ask how long you’ve been using a particular technology.
Michael is probably fine too. Even better in my opinion.
Happy to help. Can you take a look at my resume? And I will post it here tomorrow.
As for the university, something like this would look better. But I'm not a recruiter.
- Faculty of Aerospace Systems - National Technical University of Ukraine

*substitute the required department*
Just keep in mind that under NDA, in many such companies, you cannot publicly mention the name of the project and the company you actually worked for.)
You do not violate NDA if you only mention the client company, as there's no visible link with your consulting company in the resume. However, if you list both companies together on one line - consulting and client, that would be a breach and not good :) I would also advise mentioning the client company only if you worked exclusively for one client during that period. For example, an architect in consulting might have several clients at once, so it wouldn’t be entirely honest to mention just one of them ;)

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

The job description is well written. I like it; I would just add a summary of 2-3 sentences at the top, stating that you are such-and-such a developer with such-and-such experience and a couple of standard things that represent you in a favorable light.
In the resume, there are descriptions of either achievements or responsibilities that are self-evident for a developer. For the American market, rename the file to resume (and don’t call it CV verbally either). You need to add a summary. All the bullets merged into one continuous text; it needs to be cleaned up. For example, "utilized tools such as Jira and Confluence" can be safely removed. You can add Jira and, for example, Agile or Scrum to the tech skills if you want. Please definitely remove the visa status; it really gives away a newbie on the American market. Where did you study at school 21? I heard good reviews about them, but they seem to have closed in the states?

In the summary, there's a lot of fluff; rewrite or remove it.

> Implementing different React components doesn’t carry meaningful weight; it's self-evident, yet you've placed it at the top as a main achievement.

Participating / Maintaining / Responsible for implementing, etc. is poorly stated; write in the format: Accomplished [X] as measured by [Y], by doing [Z].
+ Experience needs to be completely rewritten in the Canadian format for better ATS readability. The formula was already suggested above.
+ Rename CV to resume. CV is for professors and other academic figures, listing research, publications, presentations, etc.
+ Add a link to your GitHub and/or a site with projects.
+ I would remove the certificates entirely; you already have a Bachelor's in Computer Science (by the way, both words should start with a capital letter, and so should both words in Professional Experience).
+ The start of bullet points is also typically capitalized here.
+ Limit to only 2 colors maximum; change gray to black.
+ Regarding the summary, you were already advised above. Write in a way that will catch the recruiter’s attention.
+ Specify the phone number in this format: +1 778 650 9609 or with a dash.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

      technologies: Java
      dates: Apr 2022

    - title: Tech Orda Scholarship

      description: Chosen as one of 75 candidates out of 4000+ applicants (acceptance rate: 2%).

The first thing that stands out is the university. I would recommend moving it a little lower and not indicating 2027 as the end date; just mention when you started and that you are currently studying. Also, I think universities don't just teach C++, but also cover the basics of other programming languages (I advise removing the courses).
The word "utilizing" and others like it are jarring (I was a heavy user of JPT for a couple of months, and in my opinion, all HRs are using it now and will immediately realize you used it. As someone in this group said, "You'll automatically be at an advantage if you rephrase it using more commonly used words in life").
I would recommend listing projects chronologically, as it's not clear whether this is the end or the beginning of the project.
It is also advisable to specify where (city, country) that experience took place.
Why are AWARDS and Projects different? You have to make each part capitalized or not.
Remove the used tools from the projects and add them to the technical skills; otherwise, readability suffers.
You can make links to GitHub projects by wrapping the project names in href, coloring them blue, and underlining them — this will give us links to GitHub projects without the extra word "GitHub" after the technologies. If the project does not have a link to GitHub, you can simply remove its underline.

The Nomad Shot project leads to a 404, apparently a private repo.
For Rock-Paper-Scissors Star Wars Edition, the readme is lacking a description. For code highlighting, instead of ''' [code]''' you can use '''java [code]''' or specify any other language there.

1. Choose a single name and stick with it. For example, Alex, as your nickname in this chat.
2. Revise the summary (expand it a bit). I don’t know if it’s appropriate to say seasoned. Write the number of years as digits. Remember that a recruiter will spend 5-6 seconds on first glance, and the first thing that catches the eye from solid text is numbers.
3. Move the skills up, right after the summary.
4. In the line with your name, add Software Developer (or whatever is accepted in Canada) through | or ●.
5. I would remove 'Remote' from each position and write the headquarters location instead.

Everything else is good.

1. Choose a single name and stick with it. For example, Alex, as your nickname in this chat.
2. Revise the summary (expand it a bit). I don’t know if it’s appropriate to say seasoned. Write the number of years as digits. Remember that a recruiter will spend 5-6 seconds on first glance, and the first thing that catches the eye from solid text is numbers.
3. Move the skills up, right after the summary.
4. In the line with your name, add Software Developer (or whatever is accepted in Canada) through | or ●.
5. I would remove 'Remote' from each position and write the headquarters location instead.

Everything else is good.

Thank you very much!
A few questions (actually, just one)
1. I tied my name to official documents, hence the discrepancy. I've had to explain this before. Is it customary to indicate in the CV the name you prefer to be called?
2. Valuable information, thank you!

In the US/Canada, a preferred name is usually written. For immigrants, it’s typical to adapt names to a more readable/pronounceable version. For example, Yauheniya becomes Jane. Alexander, if he doesn't want to be called AleGZandər, becomes Alex. Similarly, Joseph often writes Joe (Biden).
My name is Magdurashem (this is fake)

How to make it more readable in English?

Would Alex work?
Oh yes, I hate their Zəndər.
Morgan, Madison

I had to change from Artem to Thomas, otherwise I wouldn’t get interviews.
Sarcasm detected. If you think my advice about names is wrong, please write your opinion in detail. I'd be happy to concede and stop responding. Thank you for your attention.
Did you correct it in the resume? Or in LinkedIn, for example, too?
I’ve only encountered women with the name Madison.
I’ve only created a profile-clone on LinkedIn so far. Thomas gets contacted constantly, Artem does not. The profiles are identical.
A bit off-topic. Greetings from Plovdiv.
Chinese and Indians get contacted right away.
Wow.
Does it allow creating a second profile? I've seen complaints that it doesn't let owners of upgraded profiles create clones in other languages. There might be a difference in SSI and scoring with HRs.
Incredible. I need to try it, thank you!)
Hello!
Tell me, for those who are out of the loop, where can I view this metric and how can I increase it?
Connect with the right people from your industry or institution, comment on articles, repost.

Can you please critique/evaluate my resume? I would be grateful!

- Django, ,PostgreSQL — two commas in a row.
- Postman Swagger — these are different tools, no comma.
- Clean Architecture - what pattern or approach is this?
- Stack:React.js — space after the colon is missing.
- React.js seems to have been renamed simply to React (front-end developers can throw crap at me if I'm wrong)
- Broken link to GitHub https://https//

↳ Writing the stack before the project description and duplicating it in the description makes no sense.
↳ Your achievement for the business is not that you Collaborated, but that you developed. What number of active users did the project achieve? What product metrics can you list that your team achieved because of you?
↳ Django (backend), PostgreSQL (database), and React.js (frontend) - there is no sense in writing what the language or tool is for, if it's an industry standard. Obviously, PostgreSQL = this RDMS = database in your case. It's more important to show technical depth. Within any programming language, DB, framework, library, tool, there are deep aspects that are applied in projects to increase peak input/output operations, replication, sharding, reducing downtime...


↳ How many users? How much time did users spend making decisions before and after this implementation? What changed for the better in their lives?

↳ This is not an achievement, but a responsibility.


The last position is in front-end, but it's not clear what job you are looking for: full-stack, front-end? You need to change the title of the last position if it's full-stack.

The resume should help achieve career and life goals by emphasizing your accomplishments. If you want to go to Canada, there are two obvious options: remote work or an employer with LMIA.

- Indicating a desired job title like "Software Developer (NOC 21232)" is good for applying to positions where there is a chance of getting a job offer for immigration programs. This resume will be strengthened by official language exam results (English/French) such as IELTS.
- To understand the likelihood of immigration through a company, look for LinkedIn employees from CIS countries.
- Use "Software Engineer" if the position is titled that way in the job listing. An engineer has fundamental training and can solve a broader range of tasks than just a developer.

- Don't label the section; just list contacts.
- Hide GitHub, as it has an unprofessional profile picture and outdated code from three years ago.

- Middle Software Developer. The grade will be determined in the interview. By North American standards, you are a junior. However, it’s better to just write "Software Developer" for immigration job applications and "Software Engineer" for the wider job market and remote work.
- Selling yourself should start with the company where you work. Write selling text focusing on the scale of engineering tasks, distribution, and the number of clients, or just state that it's the top bank in Eastern Europe.

↳ What is the number of external and internal users impacted by these microservices? 
↳ What technical metrics can underline your engineering expertise? Latency? Zero-bug tolerance? Throughput? Concurrent users? 
↳ Show technical managers metrics and practices used in system design while describing your achievements.
↳ What caused the revenue growth? Did you build microservices from scratch that scale horizontally for what purpose?
↳ Why both programming languages, Java and Kotlin? Surely, there’s something to be proud of without violating NDA.
↳ What were the timelines for the work done?
↳ What business processes or operational processes were positively impacted and how? 


↳ java → Java
↳ core - you need to elaborate on the scope. Load/data volume/powerful engineering metrics = level of responsibility. Thus, metrics and delta of change should be provided.
↳ If you accelerated development after eliminating legacy bad code, then where did the deployment acceleration come from? You need to elaborate on what the basis was. It could also be a corporate cloud, which would further enhance your resume.


↳ This hints at your work as a manager. If you want to land a job with a managerial slant, provide more figures on how much money was saved, earned, or not lost.
↳ There is absolutely no scale or complexity. If you had written that you saved over $10M by developing and implementing integration automated tests for payment processing and… then elaborated on how that was achieved.

↳ Just rename the section
↳ Add THE DETAILS in projects that will be your competitive advantage over other candidates.
↳ Show scale through the number of downloads, verified documents, users. And engineering strength through technical metrics, architectural approaches, detailed tuning of libraries and architectural methods.

As a thank you, you might confirm my skills.
Hello! What kind of profile pictures on GitHub are considered professional?

The resume should help achieve career and life goals by emphasizing your accomplishments. If you want to go to Canada, there are two obvious options: remote work or an employer with LMIA.

- Indicating a desired job title like "Software Developer (NOC 21232)" is good for applying to positions where there is a chance of getting a job offer for immigration programs. This resume will be strengthened by official language exam results (English/French) such as IELTS.
- To understand the likelihood of immigration through a company, look for LinkedIn employees from CIS countries.
- Use "Software Engineer" if the position is titled that way in the job listing. An engineer has fundamental training and can solve a broader range of tasks than just a developer.

- Don't label the section; just list contacts.
- Hide GitHub, as it has an unprofessional profile picture and outdated code from three years ago.

- Middle Software Developer. The grade will be determined in the interview. By North American standards, you are a junior. However, it’s better to just write "Software Developer" for immigration job applications and "Software Engineer" for the wider job market and remote work.
- Selling yourself should start with the company where you work. Write selling text focusing on the scale of engineering tasks, distribution, and the number of clients, or just state that it's the top bank in Eastern Europe.

↳ What is the number of external and internal users impacted by these microservices? 
↳ What technical metrics can underline your engineering expertise? Latency? Zero-bug tolerance? Throughput? Concurrent users? 
↳ Show technical managers metrics and practices used in system design while describing your achievements.
↳ What caused the revenue growth? Did you build microservices from scratch that scale horizontally for what purpose?
↳ Why both programming languages, Java and Kotlin? Surely, there’s something to be proud of without violating NDA.
↳ What were the timelines for the work done?
↳ What business processes or operational processes were positively impacted and how? 


↳ java → Java
↳ core - you need to elaborate on the scope. Load/data volume/powerful engineering metrics = level of responsibility. Thus, metrics and delta of change should be provided.
↳ If you accelerated development after eliminating legacy bad code, then where did the deployment acceleration come from? You need to elaborate on what the basis was. It could also be a corporate cloud, which would further enhance your resume.


↳ This hints at your work as a manager. If you want to land a job with a managerial slant, provide more figures on how much money was saved, earned, or not lost.
↳ There is absolutely no scale or complexity. If you had written that you saved over $10M by developing and implementing integration automated tests for payment processing and… then elaborated on how that was achieved.

↳ Just rename the section
↳ Add THE DETAILS in projects that will be your competitive advantage over other candidates.
↳ Show scale through the number of downloads, verified documents, users. And engineering strength through technical metrics, architectural approaches, detailed tuning of libraries and architectural methods.

As a thank you, you might confirm my skills.
Hello! What kind of profile pictures on GitHub are considered professional?

Does it make sense to remove the Projects section altogether and make Work Experience more comprehensive? Given your edits, it might not fit on one page. Plus, the projects there are not relevant for a Java developer position.
I made some adjustments, removed projects, added more bullet points, and emphasized teamwork more (since these are mostly team achievements, not just mine). I don't have access to business metrics to assess my impact on them; I only use the ones the PO sometimes shares with us.

If you are strategically approaching your career and are 100% sure you need to maintain GitHub to showcase your portfolio, then:
- Use the same photo on LinkedIn, GitHub, and messengers.
- Try to have the same username across all social media.
↳ This is the basis for personal branding and saves mental energy for recruiters. Recruiters have a ton of tabs open, and if someone is easily recognizable on all their profiles, it means you've cared about the hiring side.

- On GitHub, besides the link to LinkedIn and your photo, you should definitely describe your projects so that a non-programmer understands: what value your code has, what problem/issue you were solving, why, how it can potentially be used in business, and how it improves people's lives.
- In essence, you can describe your repos using the STAR framework without showing a graveyard of code. This could help recruiters realize that you care about business and people, which means you're better than 99% of other candidates in equal circumstances. Few engineers are ready to think and demonstrate their business thinking.

The fact is, companies can choose candidates who will bring maximum ROI in a specific position.
Well, you've answered your question :) Of course, after 3 years of work experience, projects are only shown by those who are drastically changing their career vector and want to shift from frontend to backend, for example, or from development to PM roles.
You should consider changing your email; in an English-speaking environment, it's at best unclear and, for Russian speakers, sounds unprofessionally loud. 
<name>.<surname>@example.com would be best.
Thank you very much for the response!
I support you.
Instead of some strange transliterate mastep70, a more appropriate name would be regular pussy.hunter70.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

document:
  sections:
  - type: education
    order: 1
    content:
    - institution: Constructor University (former Jacobs University Bremen)
      degree: B.Sc. Computer Science
      gpa: 1.79 (0 being best)
      location: Bremen, Germany
      dates: July 2022 — June 2023
    - institution: National Research University Higher School of Economics
      degree: B.Sc. Applied Mathematics and Computer Science
      location: Saint-Petersburg, Russia
      dates: August 2019 — June 2022
      note: Transferred to Jacobs University
    - completedCourses:
      - type: courses
        subjects:
        - Computer Science: "Algorithms and Data Structures, C++, Python, Java, Computer Vision, Machine Learning"
        - Maths: "Linear Algebra, Graph Theory, Calculus, Probability Theory, Mathematical Statistics"
  - type: experience
    order: 2
    content:
    - company: Google
      role: Software engineering internship, Population Health team
      dates: July 2023 — September 2023
      accomplishments:
      - "Automated patient cohort definition using Clinical Quality Language code generation for internal use"
      - "Integrated a code generation into the pipeline with Google Cloud and BigQuery for convenient results observation"
      stack: "Java, proto, SQL, Google Cloud Platform, BigQuery, Python, Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR)"
    - company: JetBrains
      role: Software engineering internship, Fleet UI team
      dates: December 2022 — June 2023
      accomplishments:
      - "Incorporated code review UI functionality into the Fleet IDE"
      - "Implemented an UI for code reviews including timeline visualization, file diffs, and inline comments"
      stack: "Kotlin"
    - company: Google
      role: STEP internship, Google Shopping, Content API team
      dates: August 2022 — October 2022
      accomplishments:
      - "Launched to production a new API method in Content API"
      - "Integrated a new quota management system, enhancing thousands of users’ experience during peak shopping seasons"
      - "Developed an internal web tool for manual quota allocation, increasing team productivity and operational efficiency"
      stack: "Java, Kotlin, proto, SQL, TypeScript, HTML"
  - type: projects
    order: 3
    content:
    - title: Samwise library
      description: "Python library with pandas interface for big data analysis with minimal RAM usage"
      stack: "Python, pandas"
    - title: Bank ledger with server
      description: "Console bank application with TCP-server"
      stack: "C++, Python, boost.asio"
      accomplishments:
      - "Experience in implementing concurrent algorithms and bringing parallelism to C++ projects"
      - "Implemented thread-safe user transaction monitoring"
  - type: skills
    order: 4
    content:
    - programmingLanguages:
      - professionalExperience: "Java, Kotlin, Python"
      - extensiveKnowledge: "C++, SQL, Haskell, HTML, CSS, React, TypeScript"
    - tools:
      - "proto, Make, CMake, SVN, Git, Google Cloud Platform, BigQuery, Java FX, numpy, scipy"
    - communication:
      - "English (C1, IELTS 8.0), Russian (native), German (A2), French (A2)"
  - type: achievements
    order: 5
    content:
    - "2023, my bachelor’s thesis 'Algorithm for finding orthologous immunoglobulin genes' led to a research collaboration with 10 bioinformatics scientists from top U.S. universities and a forthcoming publication"
    - "2022, awarded a JetBrains educational grant for transferring to Germany as one of the top Russian CS students"

Are you looking in Europe?
At first glance, the resume looks great, I'm even a bit envious) I can only point out that, I don't know about Europe, but in the USA they look at achievements numerically. Accomplished [X] as measured by [Y], by doing [Z] as an example. But I don't think that's the problem given all the other achievements, rather the timing is just unfortunate( You can also check how it's parsed, maybe there's an issue.
Americans usually have grades from 1 to 4, where 4 is the highest. 1.79 is quite low. "1.0 being best" they might not notice. But this is for the American market.
How to understand a new grad position? Is it pre-junior?
Could you please tell me what font is used in this resume?

If I understood the question correctly — to get an internship, you most often need to be a university student, but unfortunately I've already graduated.

Ah, well, in the CIS it’s just standardized. Seems like it's quite challenging to pivot into IT if you want to change your profession.

I understood, thank you.

I am very grateful!

It's best not to indicate this at all, in my opinion; no one is interested in knowing that you speak other languages besides English.
I would replace 'technical' with B2.
Exactly, exactly. But there are positions where they specifically indicate languages like German, Polish, etc. So thinking that besides English nothing interests anyone is a bit much.
There's barely a B2 there, at best maybe A1.5.)
Who cares if a person knows Kazakh, Russian, Ukrainian and is applying in Europe?

If you’re applying in Germany, indicating that you know German plus English might make sense.
If a company requires knowledge of languages from you, they'll ask you to list all the languages you know on the application. It's unnecessary on the resume and just takes up space.
Write it as it is. If they ask you questions and you can't follow along, it'll be awkward. 
You could also link to a certificate or the language level certificate.
Galleries in Europe often 'speak Russian'; then what? I know at least three major companies where I had interviews in Russian within teams that spoke Russian.
By the way, about languages in Europe.
I also had an interview in Russian when applying to Germany. But it's not clear, what if your name is Ivan Ivanov?

So that's not an argument at all.
When I responded, I noted that "no one needs any language other than English." But the person clung to the Russian language.
When applying for what? We're talking about IT here. I have reverse cases where HRs, not seeing the mention of Russian, ‘drove me’ to interviews, and then there was embarrassment. ‘Oh, you speak Russian.’ So yes, that’s not an argument.
Absolutely, English is a must. How can you work in IT without it?
In all the resumes above, it lists Russian, Ukrainian, Kazakh. I was implying that the presence of these languages (okay, almost) is of no interest to anyone unless you know the language of the country you're applying to (I cited the example with Germany), then it might make sense to mention it.

I don't understand what you're stuck on.)
This point was 'voiced' deliberately. But on the other hand, when the team speaks in their native language, it enhances speed and simplifies communication.
Absolutely, I always list all my languages and realistic fluency levels. I didn't study for nothing.

Projects should come first in this case.
Honestly, the projects look weak and seem like nothing—they have no details, no notable achievements or anything like that.
I made a CV for my child like this; I think it’s worth describing your achievements first, what you have done, then detailing what you have accomplished while studying. Then don't stretch the skills out too much, but rather list the experience you gained, perhaps during university or through freelance work, and what the results of your work were. It’s better to have a half-page full of information than to stretch it with skills into a whole page.

The bullet points with the Tech Stack do look strange. It’s better to choose a template where the technical stack fits seamlessly into the job description.

For project descriptions, the same format is usually used as that for job descriptions: on a separate line the project name/link/dates, optionally on the next line the tech stack, then a list of bullet points about what was done.

Here are some picky points taken from very good resume material:

Italicization, ALL-CAPS, and bolding, if used, should be used independently of each other.
If you've been out of school for a while, your section order should be: Skills > Experience > Projects > Education.
If you're a student or new grad, your section order should be: Education > Experience > Projects > Skills.
Section headings should be mixed-case, not all-caps, i.e. Skills, not.
Don't include coursework unless they are graduate electives or like underwater robotics.
Bullet points should be 2 lines or less. Aim for 1 line.
Don't end bullet points with periods. Bullet points are not sentences.
1 sentence per bullet.
Don't spill bullets onto the following line with only 1–5 words on it. It's an extreme waste of space.
If it will be needed at work, then yes.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

        fontSize: 12px
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'

Yes, but if you don't indicate a language, it gives the impression that you speak English by default, and writing B1 or B2 is only a disadvantage.
That's true. B2 is too little for work, so that level definitely shouldn’t be listed.
With B1 in English, I don't think you will be considered, especially in America. Write at least B2, it doesn't matter what it actually is.
If you don't have language certificates, you can write intermediate; many HRs usually give a high level for fluency even with terrible grammar!)
In my opinion, it's better to remove the language section for the USA.
Remove B1 and so on.
The first paragraph is centered, but the second is not. Still, remove the languages (you can add them if needed by tailoring the resume to the job).
Squad is more about the army than programming. You need to add more specifics about the application area, how many users, how much profit there was for the company, and what improvements you made regarding development, best practices, etc. You can look for analyses by Alexander Valuyev here in the chat. They highlight the logic of resume writing well, even if they aren't specifically about mobile apps.
Hardly anyone is interested in what languages you know other than English, and by stating your English level, you're just giving an unnecessary reason for doubt.
Me: I know Python
Everyone: No one cares, English is better
:DDD
P.S. Just a moment of humor.
In the USA, it matters. In many companies, it will be a plus.
For example, in which ones? Name a couple.
In most cases, in none unless you hit it off with fellow countrymen.
In Chase, they told me that languages are a plus. I'm not saying that it's really important, but as a small advantage.
For a programmer position? I highly doubt it. If it's as a consultant in an office in Brighton, then maybe.
Diversity, though. Recruiters first look at the resumes, and with everything being equal, such a small plus can matter. If there's room to keep languages, it's worth it.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

What a meeting this is!
It looks great to me, everything is on point, nothing superfluous. I can only advise adding metrics to the achievements.
Your sentence constructions are very simple and lack colorful adjectives that emphasize how important your contributions were, what a great specialist you are, etc. There are many action verbs 🙂 The text is a bit dry - you write more about what you did rather than the importance of it.

I would remove English B2 from the second line - you can mention that in the summary. The position, employer, and work dates can all fit into one line to save space.

The second position does not have a specified title.
Could you send me the template privately, if it's not too much trouble?

Hello! 
The summary is one water, feels like GPT. Be sure to change it, check how others above do it.
In skills, there aren't many items; I believe for juniors it's better to write more technologies, even if they are similar. For example, FastAPI and Flask. Remove the IDE, nobody cares.
Soft skills are just one water without results, skills are not confirmed by anything. Either show results or remove it.
Interests can be left, a little refreshes from the overall dullness of reading 100+ resumes.
Very weak summary, in your case it should be outstanding; no need to highlight with bold text and underline, it's better to remove phone icons and other decorations.
In general, it's better to tailor the resume for a specific vacancy, look at the neural network which has ATS built-in to see how well your resume matches the job posting.
The first point in experience is somewhat murky; what does fully-functional mean? Is everything else not fully functional? Real world size? Showcase portfolio? Is this a pet project or work?
"Implemented knowledge of Java and Spring Framework for completing a real-world technical task example;" - did he bring knowledge to life? 😵
Nobody can, but he could :D

Resume for Europe*

1) The resume is written for a specific vacancy and, ideally, should be adapted to specific responsibilities. And here arises the question: do you want to be a back-end developer or do you want to be a Backend Development Instructor? Or are you open to any proposal? In that case, create two resumes. If you're creating the back-end developer resume, your experience as an instructor is relevant, but it should only be mentioned in the Summary or Cover Letter. If you decide to create a separate resume for the instructor role, of course, you need to elaborate on your experience in detail (and highlight your developer experience).

2) The SKILLS section is an important section for a technical person; it should be located at the top under the Summary. For readability, it’s better to split it into Languages and Frameworks or something similar, but avoid overwhelming the reader with an alphabetical jumble. Naturally, what you are strongest in should come to the forefront.

3) The SUMMARY needs rewriting; there is a lot of fluff ("Have experience with different types of architecture and technologies" - this sentence tells nothing about you). It’s important to understand which role you’re aiming for.
Hello!
Skills are great.
Experience is good; for example, you can show it for mid-level positions.
Sasha Tomsky's comments are useful; I thought of adding something myself, but he already covered everything.
Are you definitely leaving?)

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

I will be a bore, but... since you are new here. In the chat, there are messages where people made 300-500-1000 applications without any progress. Unfortunately. 
You just have to keep sending them out. Well, that's the minimum.
At least photos shouldn't be in resumes (for the EU).
You can also read the pinned messages; I think it would be better to detail the bullet points instead of taking up space on the right.
There are no dates; it's unclear how much experience there is.
Experience needs to be described better; there are examples in the chat.
Remove the photo, and I'm also doubtful about the hobbies being necessary.
Projects on GitHub can also be removed if there is experience, only if they are not popular.
Perhaps it would be worth changing the template from two-column to a regular one.

Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.

Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

I am committed not only to writing clean and maintainable code, fully covered by tests, but also to enhancing project metrics related to features I'm working on.
      fontFamily: Arial

      textColor: '#000000'
  - type: skills

    content:

      fontFamily: Arial

    - list:
      - App modularization
      - Auto Layout
      - CocoaPods
      - Combine
      - Core Animation
      - DRY
      - Figma
      - Firebase
      - GCD
      - git
      - GitFlow
      - Keychain
      - KISS
      - MVC
      - MVVM
      - Objective-C
      - OOP
      - Real, RxSwift
      - SnapKit
      - SOLID
      - SPM
      - Storyboard
      - Swift
      - SwiftGen
      - SwiftLint
      - Tuist
      - UDF
      - UIKit
      - unit testing
      - XcodeGen
      - XCTest
      fontFamily: Arial
      fontSize: 14
      fontWeight: normal
      textColor: '#000000'
  - type: employment
    order: 4
    content:
    - company: VK
      role: iOS Engineer
      date: May 2022 - Dec 2023
      description: (Cloud - AppStore top-3 cloud storage app in its domestic region, Mail.ru - AppStore top-1 email client superapp in its domestic region.)
      accomplishments:
      - Reduced time-to-market by 30% for new features related to file viewing by implementing a new file viewer module in Cloud app. Made the module remotely configurable and reusable for other teams.
      - Decreased the number of user billing profile loading failures by 83% through refactoring billing profile handling logic and rewriting it from Objective-C to Swift in Cloud. Increased the domain code test coverage by 96%.
      - Designed and developed a cross-app feature that allows users to open email attachments from the email client superapp inside the cloud storage app.
      - Regularly participated in the company’s internal tech talks as a speaker. Presented "Switching from RxSwift to Combine in a project" and "Swift compiler performance" tech talks.
    - company: JivoChat
      role: iOS Engineer
      date: Aug 2020 - May 2022
      description: (top-3 business messenger worldwide by the number of users.)
      accomplishments:
      - Developed a mobile SDK from scratch for audience of 200K+ clients.
      - Implemented 3 APIs for the SDK - Swift, Objective-C, and JavaScript (ReactNative); supported 6 major iOS versions; supported all the future Xcode versions by adding module stability support for the SDK binary.
      - Wrote complete documentation of 55K+ characters for the SDK.
      - Was directly communicating with 15 clients’ development teams at once, solving the SDK integration issues, collecting feedback, and improving the product based on that.
    - company: Appricot
      role: iOS Developer
      date: Aug 2019 - Aug 2020
      description: (app for a forex broker platform with more than 2 million traders.)
      accomplishments:
      - Increased user proof of identity/residence completion rate by 13% through implementation of a new identity and residence verification flow.
      - Rate of user conversion to funded account holders was increased by 14% with implementation of demo account creation flow.
      - Increased users onboarding completion rate by 11% after implementing a new onboarding flow.
      - Developed country/region-specific features. Such as added RTL UI direction support for the whole app.
  - type: education
    order: 5
    content:
    - institution: Volgograd State Technical University.
      degree: Bachelor’s degree in Applied Computer Science.
      date: Sep 2016 - Jul 2020
      notes: Graduated with honors (with honors).
      project: Graduation project: a mobile app that helps to prepare for the post-school Unified State Exam.
      fontFamily: Arial
      fontSize: 14
      fontWeight: normal
      textColor: '#000000'

Remove the emojis, first and foremost) It looks unserious.
Is +7 a Vietnamese number?
Remove the last sentence in the summary, throw out the words audience, the number of characters in documentation, improved the product accordingly. Change the passive voice to active in one place before experience. Instead of as an example, added, just say such as. Add "with honors" in parentheses to the previous line. Also remove the project about the Unified State Exam; it's puzzling for foreigners.

Remove the last sentence in the summary, throw out the words audience, the number of characters in documentation, improved the product accordingly. You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

I think (maybe I'm wrong) there's a lack of clear positioning. It seems like you're invited to read the summary and skills and think about which role such a talent could apply to.)
"quantitative problem-solving capabilities" — who writes such texts for you? that's just ridiculous... are you a robot or a device?))) can't you write something that people can understand, like "ability to solve math problems"?

And for the first time, I disagree with all previous commenters.
The positioning in data analysis in finance is, in principle, grasped.
"Quantitative" is the right word, you can't change it to "math."
In principle, the positioning can be strengthened - but just by adding the word "quantitative" everywhere.

For example, in the first phrase of the summary: "Master Student in quantitative finance"

In the top line of work experience:
"Quantitative Business Analyst"

And so on. 

But this is if you really expect lazy and disengaged HRs.
After ChatGPT writes smart words, please check yourself; it needs to be written.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

In which country are you interested in working? I understand you want to sell yourself as a frontend developer with an understanding and background in backend?
It seems like there are two jobs indicated for the same period? If so, mention part-time or don't reveal two full-time positions.

Good day, yes that's correct. No specific location. Europe or the States.
Yes, it's one office with two firms inside.

* In my opinion, the "languages" section adds nothing. I would remove the entire section. People who receive the resume in English will assume you know English. Other languages don't add value for the US and Europe. For the Russian-speaking context and for Armenia, I would create a separate resume. This section would be useful if you spoke German or Spanish, for Europe it would be beneficial.
* The Summary section overall contributes little; I would remove lengthy phrases to make it more straightforward. For example, instead of "I have experience," say, "Experience in multiple application domains, including construction management, education, and ERP system integration." Passionate about building engaging web interfaces. Used my backend development background to contribute to multiple full-stack initiatives. Ideally, this would include examples from your experience and metrics, for instance, your colleagues had an average bug-fixing time of 1 week because they had to coordinate between frontend and backend, but yours was 2 days because you understand both sides.
* From the job descriptions, I would remove responsibilities and keep only achievements. From responsibilities, I would take the best-sounding points (like "led projects") and place them separately after the position title. In achievements, it's desirable to add metrics. For example, in your current job, the second bullet point, "improved site performance," should specify by how much. In the next job, "brought projects from conception to MVP," could include some details? Budget, how long the project took, what happened to this MVP—was additional funding allocated for it, how many users it had, etc.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

1) 
What a sentimental story, I'm a junior who knows nothing and can't do anything.. besides, the title is too long. It needs to be 1-2 lines that highlight you from the crowd, not the opposite. You can share your stories later if asked. 
Don't write that you're a junior and you have half a year, with the same success, you can write - please throw my resume in the trash...
On the contrary, write what highlights you, plus experience in legal

Something like this:
I love Data! Enjoying every minute I spend on data crunching and analysis.
You have got data to be analyzed? I will get the most out of it. I got a unique combination of a strong analytical mindset and close attention to details.
What makes me one of the best candidates for your Data Analyst role in the market. (better call saul)

2) Remove locations from the job positions, Moscow, Egypt - all that doesn't help only hinders.

3) There are no achievements. For what data were you analyzing? Improve something? Help someone? At least write a couple as bullet points.

4) There are no metrics, sizes of databases, volumes of data, complexity of queries - any technical details showing the difficulty of the work.

5) Head of Legal Support Department - no need for 'head',
write that you were a support specialist, you are applying for an individual contributor role, don't scare people with heads. A manager is likely a minus since you are a junior in the gap and then you are suddenly a head/manager. If you want to be the main, write that you "Led" and not managed.

6) SIS-DEVELOPMENT - what you wrote is of no interest for the analyst position. Remove the courts and other irrelevant and write only what is relevant for the analyst. Even counting letters and pages is more useful than "sued a scoundrel cat."

7) Simplify the education, don't confuse an American's brain and only indicate the year of graduation. No need for intervals.

Finance University 2018
Bachelor of Law 

Plekhanov University of Economics 2020
Masters in Business Management

Data Analyst Practicum 2023
IBM Data Analyst 2024

What kind of processing? Why? $4000, if it's gross, and if it's a small or slightly larger company, this money can be 90% statistical error or seasonality, which reduces your contribution to 0. Here you need to write more clearly.

Why? Google Mail does this automatically, as do many other corporate emails. How did this impact the business? Or were you given this to fill time?

Here it's already better, but it would be good to write a little about the system itself. What does "ensuring reliability and scalability" mean - this is just fluff; it needs to be clearly stated how you ensured all this.

Booking what? Why did you do this if booking systems like Booking are already quite effective and accurate?

This is just fluff; what’s the final result?

How did databases and HTML end up in one line under Technologies? You could throw in internal combustion engines and metal casting too.

      fontFamily: sans-serif
      fontSize: 12
      fontWeight: normal
      textColor: '#000000'

1. Summary:
- Why 'product and startup experience'? It usually makes sense to show Startup and Enterprise as two diametrically opposed sets.
- Domain expertise should come straight in the first sentence. Please move 'fintech, robotics, IoT, web, SAAS, telecom, and IT-outsourcing' to the start. According to marketing principles, start with the advantages.
- 2-3 key measurable achievements in the Summary. Need to grab attention with metrics, not adjectives.

2. Experience
- Each job is described, but WITHOUT scale amplifiers: revenue, number of people, market share, rankings, number of offices, transaction volume.
- What does 'team productivity by a third' mean? What exactly is measured in productivity? Concrete process metrics before and after are needed. If they weren't measured, then build a hypothesis and find a way to prove that hypothesis in the interview. But you will have to quantify your impact. In addition to metrics, it will help to understand the number of teams and people so that the recruiter understands the scale of your influence.
- The theme 'transparent and efficient workflow' is NOT revealed. To reduce assumptions and conjecture, show HOW exactly your work, tools, and processes allowed a 35% reduction in defects (where, by the way?). If you implemented monitoring, code analysis, automated tests by changing the development team's attitude towards the product - great. But show how the people you influenced the mindset of started to act DIFFERENTLY. Earlier they hammered nails with a microscope, now they do it with a hammer.

- Everywhere start your achievements NOT WITH THE PROCESS, but with THE RESULT. And describe the processes with an answer to the question: how exactly was this result achieved?
- Launched a rhythmic Release Train - 100500 ways to do this knowing the theory. But you found the recipe and it worked. IN PRACTICE. And there's no point in writing that you used the theory. Show what you did in practice, so it's clear that the framework underlies your effective actions.

- Enumerating products (arm Pulse and servo-motors rDrive) makes sense only if you are responding to positions in the same business field and competitors/colleagues will happily buy your expertise. It's better to operate with product metrics without naming the products themselves if they aren't well-known to the general public. After all, for me as a recruiter, it's important that you reduced time to market through certain changes within certain deadlines and helped (directly or indirectly) the products achieve such MAU, DAU, ROI, Market Share, Retention, Churn, NPS, CSAT, Store Rank.

A round of respect for the research works, I'll throw in some insights.
"PhD in Engineering Systems + MSc in CS, Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology (Skoltech)" - ATS will break here and parse incorrectly, either remove the master or split it.

The publication section will also parse incorrectly - make a separate category for Honors and add it there.

"Visiting student, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, USA" - this is tricky. It seems like MIT, but just a visiting student. IMHO, this is like including online courses from Harvard in a resume.

You have columns somewhere - do not use columns, ATS often does not understand that. When I wanted to copy all the text, the text selection began to act up - this means there are columns.
Regarding education: keep MIT for sure, just write which department. Remove "Completed courses in." "Climbed to" sounds pompous, just put in parentheses (ranked 65 ...). It’s called PhD committee, jury sounds more like a jury trial. ;)

You understood the overall concept of the resume perfectly, now it just needs polishing.

It's not immediately clear what you are - an architect, product owner, or DevOps.

Are 2 days a lot or a little? Maybe in the context of the business, it may even mean nothing if you don't provide relative figures

What if the plan was made but then thrown out? I've seen how plans change as quickly as gloves when the market shifted. Here you need to indicate the impact on the business from another side, or in another way

Again, system security in a vacuum - that's a waste of money. For instance, if the company isn't interesting to anyone, then it can afford to neglect critical issues for 2-3 months or just cover the costs post-hack instead of addressing them preemptively. I believe companies in the US understand this well, so I recommend presenting that point differently

For now, that's all from me - I'll continue with my affairs.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

I would remove Python, Java, and C++ since you're focused on front-end, and I would also remove the line about databases unless you have interesting experience in administration or writing stored procedures or performance improvement, in which case it should be clearly specified.
At first, I thought, what's wrong with this good CV? But then I realized you're applying for a front-end role, which is a different world. There are many important things: not hanging the interface when data comes, design and layout, CSS/SCSS, and specific libraries like RxJS, Redux, etc. From the entire set in the CV, it looks more like full-stack - maybe go for that?
This might be nitpicking, but the whole text is really stretched sideways, my eyes are straining, and also my links aren't clickable—maybe a bug, email/LinkedIn are clickable, but the projects are not.

Where's the best place to add about working with databases and writing SQL statements?
Don't full stack roles require different technologies?

Full-stack allows you to handle both backend and frontend (MEAN, LEAN, etc.). I saw MongoDB there, Node, and Angular. You can have it. MongoDB, Node.js, Express (REST) for backend, React/Angular for frontend, and you can implement JWT for authorization (just don't forget to Google "never use JWT").
That's about it. SQL is very important; the main thing is to understand there is ANSI SQL, and then everything else like TSQL/PSQL/other SQL. This is important everywhere; you don't need to learn how to do simple queries: SELECT/JOIN/UPDATE/DELETE already cover 90% of requests for backend. Everything else develops as the project grows, like indexes, for example.
CORS should probably be set at the server/proxy level, like with nginx or apache, not just in technologies; it's more something that needs configuring.
While looking for a job, don't forget to read and once you get to MongoDB/Node/Express, start adding NestJS/Swagger/Auth2, or you might dive into MeteorJS and add pub/sub—next thing you know, you'll find out that the MeteorJS team created Apollo.
Hi, briefly, why is it not recommended to use JWT?
I didn't say it's a bad idea. I said you should Google 'never use JWT.' You just need to understand what freedom it gives and what obligations come with it. Many treat it as a panacea, but it's not always suitable.
What do you recommend using instead? 🤔 I recently used it in a project; it is handy, and it's hard to steal, but doing something with it is also a problem.
You don't need to replace it with anything; it's used in Firebase (Google) and Auth0. You need to read a lot and understand what's easy to steal and what's hard, and how to use them!
Just like in a joke, "Math analysis knows something; I'll just give it a 5 and let it go."
Pack the JWT in cookies, and make sure to set the appropriate flags and prefixes for the cookies.

I would be very happy to receive a review.

Wow, I didn’t expect to see someone from my city.

I would completely rewrite the summary, showing specific achievements and considering the presence of experience, so the lower education, not so high.
I think you need to decide how you want your resume to be perceived.
1. A last year student looking for an intern/junior position.
In this case, it’s perfectly fine to write in the summary primarily about education, with education being more prominent than projects, etc. Your experience will be considered as part-time work (in addition to the main activity – studying), and will give you an advantage in applying for a junior position over other graduates who do not have such experience. But, in my opinion, in this case, you shouldn’t expect anything more than junior.
2. A person with 2+ years of experience looking for junior+ positions.
In this case, you need to rewrite the summary, stating primarily about your experience, putting projects above education, and so on.
The education will then be regarded as a side project to the main activity (full-time work with already decent experience).

The resume is currently made according to point 1, but I think it needs to be changed to the second option and look for something more than junior, as all these 'some job offers above junior I fear I won’t be able to pull off' is a typical imposter syndrome. In the worst case that will happen – you won’t pass the interview, well, okay, after a certain number of failures you can rewrite it to the first option and look for something simpler, or the recruiter will take a look and say, 'Well, you don’t have enough backend experience here; we have a junior vacancy – will you try it?'
+ At the same time, looking at the interviews to see what is needed and improving your knowledge,
and to lower the bar in advance – in my opinion, it’s a bad strategy 🤷‍♂️

Languages: Russian - native, English - fluent, Python - fluent.

That's funny.
Well, depending on who this resume is for.

I understand that context from the application form would generally be sufficient, but if I were a newbie HR dealing with a pile of resumes, I would have a hard time figuring out where exactly you're headed. Mentally, it would take me a couple of minutes to remember there was a cover letter.

It's better to make it two pages and fit everything you think is important than cut off context.

HERE IN THE ATTACHMENT there is definitely a phrase that resumes are more about personal history rather than just listing achievements. For all people, even the most neuroplastic, it's tough to read texts and pick out the fun elements. It would be much more HUMAN to write a few general words without specifics about what you want to convey. Like, I'm really a dude. Just an expert.
Why separate work projects into a separate list and force people to jump back and forth or hold all this info in their head? Why not consolidate all the info about one job/project in one place?
A bit off-topic. Do they also widely use tea in Cyprus, that you mention it in your resume?

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

If you have over 3 years of experience, it would be better to include a summary section at the beginning. Overall, be more specific in describing your experience, especially regarding the tools you used.

I would remove the word "geopolitical"; it feels like you can bring some political issues into the company.
There are many general words, but little specifics. Choose achievements from work where you brought profit or reduced costs for the company and outline them clearly. The 2012 thesis is of little interest unless the company is engaged in something very similar. Regarding additional info: if your speeches are relevant to the vacancy, provide specific information with the title of the talk. Or remove it.
It's good that you are trying to keep the summary short and simple, but the way you described it is more general: ", observing async applications" would be good to be more specific... Move skills next to work experience and education and sort them better as they look very random... If you spent time with only one company for a long time, it would be good to divide them by the positions you had before or include promotions alongside your position. When it comes to capitalization, it would be good to mention which Python community you are a member of, as HR can check it. Instead of "has given multiple speeches on local conferences," it would be good to say "Speaker of ... in 2023."

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

The fact is that America cannot currently handle all the graduates and H1B. And all these guys with perfect resumes will go to the UK, to Europe. 

Their resumes are out of this world, there's nothing to criticize. And they learned to write resumes in college, with them, Career Council worked to ensure everything was top-notch. 

How to compete with them?
I confirm, here is an example of an American intern.

And among them, not a single Olympiad participant?
Two are Olympiad participants, two are not.

Well, for two it contradicts, so there’s a counterexample.

The language is poor for a resume for the USA.

What do I mean? Standard and simple phrases have mistakes.

For a graduate with a BS in IS, there are very few completed projects. Here I shared an example of a magnificent resume for US graduates, which this resume will be impossible to compete with.
There is room in the resume, it would be great to elaborate on points like "Developed two corporate portals for company employees" in more detail. Corporate portals are not just 1-2 HTML pages, there are technically complex details, I’m sure there’s something to find. For example, if you implemented an authorization/registration system, you can elaborate: "Implemented an authorization system for a corporate portal using JWT authorization: employed gRPC and its interceptors for token validation and renewal via a JavaScript library XYZ".

"Developed a component library" - what kind of component was it, what does it do? There can be details here too.

In general, it would be good to specify specifics.

Also, in the section "Developed a component library" there is a mix. It would be good to break it into several parts, perhaps remove something (like GitLab/GitHub, replacing it with Git - the hosting platform is not important, the version control system is).

"Skilled in React" - but the React versions are not indicated? As far as I remember, around version 18 there were some global changes/features.

MongoDB, by the way, is not SQL, it is document-based.

In the education section, you can indicate a list of relevant courses (for example, distributed systems/algorithms & data structures or something).
Here’s another one.

Bias towards action, great team player as well as able to deliver independently with a high focus on modern best practices and development standards.

You could call it "Publications and Preprints."
Overall, it's not bad, I have mostly minor nitpicks:
* In many places, you have metrics that are hard to interpret. For example, "achieving an accuracy of 0.97". Depending on the dataset you are working with, 0.97 can be very difficult or very easy. Ideally, you should add some business metric here, for example, that the hints provided by the system had a click-through rate of XX. If you don't have these numbers, it would be better to at least compare with something, like in the bullet point for Stepik, where you at least compare with the previous version.
* The publications are not very noticeable; if I hadn't read your message that "projects are not sorted", I would have missed them. I would either add a summary or a bullet point in the current work that "there are two publications". However, you already have many bullet points in your current job, so you should break them up somehow.
* "Successfully pitched and promoted this initiative to senior management" is a useful skill, and it should be described in more detail. Like, Designed a new feature, pitched to the CEO, secured budget for X person-months, developed and deployed the feature, which increased user engagement by X.
• Single-handedly developed multiple AI assistants using RAG to guide users through their learning paths. Conducted detailed analytical research to measure the impact of these AI assistants on user engagement.

Single-handedly developed implies that there are situations where 2 developers sit at the monitor and code.

If we bring this bullet point to normality, it would be:

Developed AI assistants using RAG to increase user engagement during the learning process by 10%.

In other bullet points, the same wording error can be seen. The project and technology are detached from the business impact.
