You could call it "Publications and Preprints."
Overall, it's not bad, I have mostly minor nitpicks:
* In many places, you have metrics that are hard to interpret. For example, "achieving an accuracy of 0.97". Depending on the dataset you are working with, 0.97 can be very difficult or very easy. Ideally, you should add some business metric here, for example, that the hints provided by the system had a click-through rate of XX. If you don't have these numbers, it would be better to at least compare with something, like in the bullet point for Stepik, where you at least compare with the previous version.
* The publications are not very noticeable; if I hadn't read your message that "projects are not sorted", I would have missed them. I would either add a summary or a bullet point in the current work that "there are two publications". However, you already have many bullet points in your current job, so you should break them up somehow.
* "Successfully pitched and promoted this initiative to senior management" is a useful skill, and it should be described in more detail. Like, Designed a new feature, pitched to the CEO, secured budget for X person-months, developed and deployed the feature, which increased user engagement by X.
• Single-handedly developed multiple AI assistants using RAG to guide users through their learning paths. Conducted detailed analytical research to measure the impact of these AI assistants on user engagement.

Single-handedly developed implies that there are situations where 2 developers sit at the monitor and code.

If we bring this bullet point to normality, it would be:

Developed AI assistants using RAG to increase user engagement during the learning process by 10%.

In other bullet points, the same wording error can be seen. The project and technology are detached from the business impact.

How's it better to show the publications? Should I highlight them in a separate section, for example, "published articles"?
I didn't quite understand. Single-handedly translates as "in solitude" (GPT rewrote it for me). "Without help from anyone else" says Google Translate.

Is the fact that the project is detached from the business impact due to the lack of some metrics showing the impact? Is retention in the feature considered impact? I can't write anything else since the rest is impossible to measure in this case.

If there are several, then yes, definitely. Publications are great especially if they are in the employer's language.
* If you plan to add a summary, you could write there, "ML Engineer with experience in LLMs... Developed and deployed novel models that improved X by Y%... Published two peer-reviewed papers."
* If not, then add a bullet point in your work or education, "Published two peer-reviewed papers."
* At the very least, highlight them in bold.

If you add a section "Publications," it will be at the very end. On one hand, not everyone will read that far if there's no bullet point above. On the other hand, it will be a pleasant surprise for those who read to the end, and the resume will end on a strong note (and right now, it ends on the fact that you know Bash).

You can also strengthen the publications. If you know the acceptance rate of the conference and it is good (below 33%), you can indicate that; if it was an oral presentation, you can also mention that. Currently, the articles don't have citations, but if they appear later, you can indicate how many citations there are and add a link to Google Scholar.

Separately, you need to decide why you want to include publications and why you titled the section "Research Projects." If you want to work as a researcher, then the resume needs to be completely rewritten. If you want to work as an engineer, then I wouldn't emphasize this too much. There may be doubts about whether you really want to be an engineer and whether you understand the difference between a Ph.D. and a commercial firm. But I'm in the USA, maybe the attitude is different in Germany.
I wouldn't emphasize 'in solitude.' It's better to rephrase it to something like 'delivered an end-to-end solution,' so the emphasis is not on one person but on knowing all aspects from start to finish. Otherwise, it raises questions like 'if the project didn't have enough resources, maybe it wasn't needed at all.'

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

It looks like a typical junior resume. Here are the bullet points. What can be said about the programmer? Well, almost nothing. There's no technical complexity, no languages, no frameworks, no algorithms. For example, they developed a system for managing activity. Wow, that's both a database and services and REST and front-end. How many events per second did the system track? What cloud? How many active users were there? And so on for each.
What does this mean?)
Do you think HRs read these bullet points?
Each task was implemented in the same framework, languages, clouds, etc. I wrote them down below. Or should I repeat the framework after each task?

During several interviews, we went through many bullet points and were asked how I calculated the numbers.
No.

But a bot reads them and gives a score, if lower - it sends a rejection.
A resume is not just sent to HR, HR just passes it along, and then the one who understands looks at this resume and realizes that they are not dealing with a programmer. Or the experience doesn't meet the requirements. Details are needed, technical details, on what and how this bullet was made. And not a single programming language is mentioned. In skills, a bunch of technologies listed all in one go, and you’re supposed to guess what and how I used from that.
And how can one understand where the expertise lies? MySQL? PHP? You will understand what I mean when you try to answer the question how? We engineers don't care about the percentage of teachers who came back. Customer satisfaction takes care of that. I'm curious where all these events were sent, the volume of messages, was there geographical distribution? Basically, I want to understand if this is a makeshift project or a real stressed system, with thousands of users and 24/7 availability.
Bullet points are scrutinized, and you need to know how to give a detailed answer for each of them in interviews. But they're unlikely to be the reason for rejection from HR.
Wow, you're really an admin here.
Seriously, how?) I honestly admitted that I improved something, while I just made up the numbers, and they hired me.)
So should I not write everything on one page?
It happens.
Well, it depends on what you wrote.
For instance, I mentioned that I implemented CI/CD and increased team performance by X percent, while the number of bugs decreased by Y%.
Explanation - simple.
Before I came, there was no CI/CD in the team, and they deployed into production without running unit and integration tests. I implemented CI/CD. Before rolling it out, I looked at the story velocity over the last conditional 3 months, the number of bugs, and the number of features taken in each sprint. Then I did the same after rolling out CI/CD; velocity increased, we could take more stories per sprint, the number of bugs decreased, calculated percentages, profit.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."

"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

Where are you heading primarily?
Do you think it’s worth writing "Most of my experience is in small projects and leading small teams or solo work. I want to dive into bigger project development, legacy, and more team play."? I would omit this, talk about domains and technologies superficially. Maybe write something like "I value good code, colleagues, and established processes" to add some water and please the recruiter. I understand that you want to get into a big project, but you can regulate that during the interview/job search phase. I don't think this should be stated in the resume.
Another example for the collection from yesterday’s discussion. A graduate of 2024, yet 4 years of experience! 🤐
I want to dive into legacy. Sounds questionable.

Thanks for the criticism! I think it’s best not to flood with unnecessary details. HRs are tired of these rivers and waterfalls.
I’m a fierce second-year student)))0)) But I need to highlight it somehow because it really sounds questionable. I just left academia for work and dropped down a course because I wasn’t dedicating time to studying.
How is it best to highlight this?

What’s wrong? :)
With this success, I can write: although I don’t have a specialized education, I’ve learned CS quietly for the past 5 years - something of that sort.
Definitely mention this in your resume as a unique phenomenon 😂
You’re no seller, speaking of 4 years you immediately get stuck and imply that all this experience was trivial, and now you’d like to work on an adult project. No, you can’t sell yourself that way. Also, the position of technician doesn’t match the claimed position, if you were a programmer, then state that - software engineer, make that your main experience. Two months of internship aren’t interesting, and selling that as the primary experience isn’t beneficial. What can be done in 2 months? Write unit tests for a microservice and fix a couple of bugs. In reality, there’s not much an intern can do in an adult project. The fact that you worked in the university lab is actually logical and sellable in the western market. But it needs to be presented as a project - WOW. Like "the internet invented something new" or "Linux came up with something." Well, you know, pioneering revolutionary technologies.
That’s true, but it’s easier to distinguish - self-taught = "self-education," and they still ask about the degree of "education." :)

It seems fine, I would maybe highlight the technologies in the text itself so they stand out and you don't have to read through everything to find them. There are many questions raised by the senior position after the internship. Senior usually means around five years of relevant work experience in a specific tech stack. Of course, with a good education and freelance work, it’s possible to land a leading position, but it still seems a bit off. Maybe just keep it as software developer or look for another title for it (lead developer? I don't know, this needs a chat opinion, in general). Perhaps remove the indication that your second job was also an internship to avoid conflict.
If time allows (if there were no gaps between jobs), I would add a few months more.

      fontFamily: 'Arial'
      fontSize: '12pt'
      fontWeight: normal
      textColor: '#000000'

    order: 2
    content:
    - text: "HTML, CSS, TypeScript, React, Redux, Next, Node, Express, MongoDB, PostgreSQL, RESTful APIs, GraphQL, Jest, MUI, Tailwind, Figma, React Query, AWS"
      fontFamily: 'Arial'
      fontSize: '12pt'
      fontWeight: normal
      textColor: '#000000'
  - type: workExperience
    order: 3
    content:
    - company: "Digital Vertex - tech services and consulting"
      role: "Full Stack Engineer"
      dates: "April 2022 - Present"
      accomplishments:
      - text: "Accomplished a 40% reduction in development time by creating a reusable library of components and UI web pages using React and the MUI components library."
        fontFamily: 'Arial'
        fontSize: '12pt'
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'
      - text: "Accomplished the migration of existing REST APIs to GraphQL, reducing the number of requests by 80% by utilizing React Query, Node.js, Express.js, Apollo."
        fontFamily: 'Arial'
        fontSize: '12pt'
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'
      - text: "Achieved a 40% reduction in page load times by optimizing website performance using Next.js, Prisma ORM, and server-side rendering (SSR), while rapidly developing various MVPs."
        fontFamily: 'Arial'
        fontSize: '12pt'
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'
    - company: "Vinson Leads LLC - marketing agency"
      role: "CEO & Software Engineer"
      dates: "Dec 2023 – July 2024"
      accomplishments:
      - text: "Successfully launched over 10 webshops using WooCommerce, delivering robust e-commerce solutions."
        fontFamily: 'Arial'
        fontSize: '12pt'
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'
      - text: "Enhanced advertising efficiency by 20x for the largest client, driving significant business growth."
        fontFamily: 'Arial'
        fontSize: '12pt'
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'
    - company: "Skinya - furniture manufacturing company"
      role: "Web Developer"
      dates: "Aug 2020 - February 2022"
      accomplishments:
      - text: "Developed and launched several high-quality websites using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and jQuery, resulting in a 90% increase in sales."
        fontFamily: 'Arial'
        fontSize: '12pt'
        fontWeight: normal
        textColor: '#000000'

    order: 4

    - institution: "Ukrainian National Aviation University"
      degree: "Master's degree in Aerospace Engineering"
      location: "Kiev, Ukraine"
      dates: "2005 - 2010"
  - type: languages
    order: 5
    content:
    - language: "English"
      proficiency: "Advanced"
    - language: "Ukrainian"
      proficiency: "Native"
    - language: "Russian"
      proficiency: "Native"

- remove the +1 from the phone number

- why just engineer and not senior engineer? this kind of modesty doesn't suit you. Here, people write 4+ years for those who graduate in 2024, but you graduated back in 2010. You could easily pass as a senior with over 7 years of experience. The difference is huge, and nobody is really interested in what you did 7 years ago.

- Full Stack Engineer -> senior fullstack engineer and indicate your current location in the USA. Even if the employer is not in the USA, it doesn't matter; what's important is where you are.

- there are a lot of percentages. You can have a couple of bullets, but don't need one in every bullet, for example, let's take this one:
Achieved a 40% reduction in page load times by optimizing website performance using Next.js, Prisma ORM,
and server-side rendering (SSR), while rapidly developing various MVPs.
and rephrase it like optimized website performance using Next.js, Prisma ORM, and server-side rendering (SSR).

The meaning hasn't changed, so why so much text?

- regarding the last job, the bullets are unrelated to the engineer's job; hiring teams is all unnecessary, focus on coding.

- languages are unnecessary.
Could you explain why the +1 should be removed from the number? I've seen it in most resumes and have never heard such feedback.

      proficiency: "Native"

- remove the +1 from the phone number

- why just engineer and not senior engineer? this kind of modesty doesn't suit you. Here, people write 4+ years for those who graduate in 2024, but you graduated back in 2010. You could easily pass as a senior with over 7 years of experience. The difference is huge, and nobody is really interested in what you did 7 years ago.

- Full Stack Engineer -> senior fullstack engineer and indicate your current location in the USA. Even if the employer is not in the USA, it doesn't matter; what's important is where you are.

- there are a lot of percentages. You can have a couple of bullets, but don't need one in every bullet, for example, let's take this one:
Achieved a 40% reduction in page load times by optimizing website performance using Next.js, Prisma ORM,
and server-side rendering (SSR), while rapidly developing various MVPs.
and rephrase it like optimized website performance using Next.js, Prisma ORM, and server-side rendering (SSR).

The meaning hasn't changed, so why so much text?

- regarding the last job, the bullets are unrelated to the engineer's job; hiring teams is all unnecessary, focus on coding.

- languages are unnecessary.
Could you explain why the +1 should be removed from the number? I've seen it in most resumes and have never heard such feedback.

Thank you!
By last, do you mean the second from the top? Vinson Leads LLC?

No, I'm talking about an earlier point - Developed and implemented comprehensive business strategies tailored to each client's needs, increasing profit by 15 times. How could a web developer develop a business strategy and increase sales by 15 times? No, that's too much.
In theory, by creating a payment form (there was nothing before this).
That's not an achievement for a web developer; salespeople sell products even without a form, and most likely there will be a government contract that the co-owner's uncle got through. 
A web developer should declare that they created a payment acceptance form in JavaScript and integrated it with the Stripe platform using library xxx, applying best practices for data security and distributed transactions.

      dates: 'Moscow, Russia, Sept. 2015 – July 2018'

A lot of Russia stands out. It's bad because without local experience it's much harder in Canada. I would recommend removing "Russia" everywhere.
When there are lots of people with local experience, they talk to people without local experience as a last resort.
>Used Terraform and Ansible
Instead of "Used," it's better to use "Integrated" or something similar.

>and reducing deployment time
It's better to add how much.

>Mentored and trained new junior system administrator, providing guidance on best practices and troubleshooting techniques
It's better to add what this led to, like reducing onboarding time.

For 2.5 years in the company, consider what else to add. Three bullet points might be too few.

> 
I don’t know how valuable this record is, but at least I would remove ".ru".
Excuse me, did you support Windows 11 in 2015 or 2017?
I would create four different, more focused resumes - for DevOps/SRE, Linux admin, Windows admin, and security analyst. I would remove all those Yandex and other .ru things as nobody knows them here, and as Artem noted earlier, it might scare off potential employers.
Then, for Technical Skills - they don't overlap with the experience description, get rid of VirtualBox - it's only used in home labs, it doesn't sell you, Zabbix - almost nobody knows it here, it's more like Nagios/Nagios XI derivatives, add RHEL to CentOS - they're practically the same, create a free developer account on RH, try out subscription management, also, Ansible - did you use Tower or AWX? If yes, mention it.
Did you work with hardware? Mention it, like out-of-band management - iLO, IPMI, iDRAC, etc.
Did you deal with storage? SAN, NAS, iSCSI, FC - mention it, did you ever do backup/disaster recovery? Mention it, if you have experience with tape libraries, documentation, RPO/RTO, stakeholder communication, etc. - include everything.
Did you set up high availability and fault tolerance? Great, write about your experience with clusters.
Did you create users in ADUC? Good, note your IAM experience, did you sort them by groups? Oh, so you configured RBAC. Did you deploy updates? Patching and vulnerability management and remediation, NIST SP 800-40 ties in well with your diploma.
Have you heard of ITIL? If not, familiarize yourself immediately, many old-fashioned firms prefer this.
"Led server and workstation virtualization efforts using MS Hyper-V hypervisors, optimizing resource utilization and scalability" - and what did you do there? Were there any P2V migrations? Where is that written? Etc.
In general - when there's a lot of diverse, loosely related stuff, it positions you as a rookie; with such a resume, you will find work only in SMBs or MSPs - both are bad, a lot of work, little money, and poor treatment.
Finally, a couple of things that significantly limit you - lack of experience with public cloud - Azure, AWS, GCP, and various tools like MS 365.
Additionally, for admin positions, it’s advisable to obtain some certifications.
And don't hesitate to throw out the PBXs, nobody really needs that.

I think the experience is better described not as a single text but in bullet points + select the most sellable parts and add some technical details. Starting with "Developed various features for several projects" doesn’t sound like a strong selling point.

If you give a link to GitHub, it makes sense to write descriptions (readme) — both for the profile as a whole and for the repositories. Examples of GitHub profiles: tiangolo, kiramclean.

Thank you, I'll edit!
I described all my experience in text just to fit everything on one page. If that's not too critical, then I'll write in bullet points.)

It's advised to stick to one page, but condense the text + write very specifically. Words like "various" or "multiple" are considered "weak" as they don't describe much.

You can ask ChatGPT to rewrite the text, experiment with different requests, for example: "Please rewrite the following description as a list of clear and concise bullet points. Ignore everything irrelevant and highlight achievements. Use strong verbs."
By the way, this might be a controversial opinion: you can remove Udemy from education, and instead create a projects section and briefly indicate the projects completed for Udemy courses.

Okay, thank you!
In general, the essence of the course is already indicated in the name, and if I describe it in a bit more detail, I will go over one page. But still, thank you, there's plenty to think about.)
The header also takes up quite a bit of space. One option is to take a template that uses space more effectively (for example, from the pinned section).

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

As a thought for the future, some European and American banks need not automation testers, but also conditional manual testers.

Well, it was mentioned above that HR evaluates resumes in the first few seconds. HR opened your resume, glanced at it, saw that you studied manual QA in 2022, and closed it—that's all.
So it's better to remove the years of education?
I would keep the higher education if you have it, and that's all. The other courses listed in your resume might rather spoil the impression. You completed them, gained knowledge, and that's good.

Well, that's understandable; I'm saying if you meet C1 and C2, it would be difficult to notice the difference between them in everyday conversations.
Good resume! The second one from the top, Paris, shifted to the left.

I would recommend tidying up the job titles a bit; maybe if you are focusing on project management, just write project everywhere (except for the lower analyst).
Is it really possible to have two Native languages? English and Russian are completely different for understanding. I'm asking because I'm really curious =)
In my understanding, usually one is Native and the other is C1.
Hi! I wouldn't use a two-column format; there may be issues with the company's ATS (Applicant Tracking System) which could prevent you from even getting to the stage of talking to a live recruiter.
Yes, it happens, but it's hard to notice the difference between C1 and C2.
Bilinguals exist, yes. But that's a rare case.
Why not? Bilingual. I have a younger one like that. English is a bit more native for him, but he can also speak Russian freely—reading, writing, thinking. But in French, he doesn't think—he translates.
The CIS countries speak Russian and one of the Turkic languages, which don't even belong to Indo-European languages.
There's a difference in vocabulary.
Yes, it's just a common story. You could, for example, visit any former USSR republic; there are plenty of such cases. It's also quite common in the USA.
Mine are the same way; though the letter "ы" is difficult for them, and it's immediately obvious which language is their first…
Well, you have a slightly different story—your mom and family aren't Russian-speaking, but for us, it's still the main language at home. When grandparents visit, the accent stops being heard.)

1) It's better to use the beloved format of Jake's resume (because it doesn't have such a variety of fonts, it's much easier to read since it reads top to bottom, not left to right as here).
2) The description of the experience in the projects looks very strange due to the unnatural sentence structure, for example, the description of the eco-market looks like the beginning of a fable by Krylov. It seems like a translator. There are mistakes, for example, 3-4 May.
3) It's better not to write that you developed project A, but instead write: in project A, I solved tasks B, C, D, and implemented this and that.
4) Description for Goodoc: Development ... planning reception and chat using GPT-4. What?
Intern/TL

It's like saying I want 200k rub, but if anything, 30k will do too.
Links aren't clickable. 
Lots of typos. 
Inconsistent fonts.

Is it even worth mentioning the bootcamp if you're still studying at the university? Like, I often understand a bootcamp as a guy, a 40+ year old locksmith who found out from his neighbor that IT specialists make a lot of money and decided to get into it. 
Probably better to indicate reliable course work (IMHO).
I don't think you should apply for a senior or mid-level+ position based on this resume. So, regarding leadership, you can completely remove it, and better to make it one column since you aren't a frontend/UX UI designer.

And one more question regarding language, is it a local trend to write half in Russian and half in English?
As mentioned above, it's better to redo it using one of the templates that are pinned.

Do you want to be an ordinary Java Developer or a team lead? If you're going for lead, then we skip intern and just keep lead.

If you're not going for lead, then there's no point in stating that you had lead responsibilities.

In general, mentioning that you were an intern is pointless, you can say that if you worked there for a short time, it's better to specify the concrete position.

The stack can be removed if it's described in the projects, that way you'll save space.

Again, the story "we in the team, we... we..." should be replaced with what exactly you did, the resume is supposed to tell about you ;)

Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

The problem with the resume is the language and the lack of knowledge of US terminology.  

Also, I wouldn’t write "founder" at the last position.  

Regarding the language:  

Java backend basis — what does that mean?  

What does "key developer" mean? Keys in Florida are islands. Siesta Key, Key Largo. Is the developer on the islands?  

The first bullet, "tracks orders" — how many? How often? There’s no number; elsewhere in the resume there are no numbers either.  

About this point:  

"Developed retail credit offering for customers in POS that brought an average of 15000 new customers per month"  

This is a typical task for a PM, not an engineer; the PM rolled out a feature that brought in clients and money. But you need to write how this was technically implemented, what it was done on, and how complex it was.
To start, you need to define the geographical area for your job search. Florida has never been the best place for Java devs, and even less so now. Remote work is becoming less common; everyone wants local hires. Since you’re looking for your first job in the USA, I would consider relocating to where there are job opportunities.  

"Built from scratch 2 scalable, high-performance apps and successfully implemented 2 data processing solutions" — is that all? In 14 years of experience, you’ve built two apps? Remove it from the summary!  

"Mostly focused on stock and crypto exchange markets with solid banking payment systems background" — If you’re specifically looking for a job in trading, you can keep it, but if it’s more general, other employers might be deterred. Because they’ll think you’re only interested in trading.  

"Founder / Key Developer (Trading)" — a co-founder of a trading application seeking a senior role is completely nonsensical for the USA. This phrasing confuses potential employers, and your resume could get tossed out.  

It’s better to be straightforward and simply write "senior dev" without the grand terms.  

AWS, Docker, Kubernetes — based on your experience, it’s unclear where these were used; it’s not mentioned anywhere.  

But these are initial thoughts; overall, you have good experience. If you direct your efforts in the right direction, you shouldn’t have issues finding a job.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

> experience
>> Research assistant
>>> LLM, GPT, AI, .. 
>> Incubator
>>> LLM

Where is the SWE experience if you're applying for an intern SWE position? Maybe it’s worth expanding the bullet points more towards SWE rather than LLM.

> Improved system efficiency, cutting response times from 1.49 to 0.99 seconds (34% improvement) through
asynchronous handling and parallel processing

The magic word "async" in Python doesn’t automatically make everything go zoom and speed up to the speed of light. This bullet point may definitely raise some questions. The same goes for parallel threads, by the way. Follow the XYZ method.

> Developed secure FastAPI endpoints for CRUD operations on objects in a MongoDB database

Same here. What measures of security are we measuring?

> shanyrak

Format the README on GitHub; everything looks scrambled there without markup. And the code as well - there's hardcoded variables, relative imports, and much more. Bring everything in general to order.

> math sensei

The same goes for "Shanyrak", but even the README is needed since it’s missing.

> tech skills

HTML/CSS are better included under languages in my opinion. In developer tools, the Python libraries, OS, Git, and Docker got mixed up. It’s better to separate them into distinct points (tools here, libraries there).

The third section of the resume contains a list of Cisco certifications, with the last position being .NET engineer. The employer won't understand what the candidate wants and will throw it in the trash. For what position is this resume?
There is a lack of logic.

Why are there 2 educational institutions? Granada adds no advantages in the US; it is better to include it in the certifications and courses section.
> education

You can remove the Erasmus in Spain; it will not bring any benefits in the USA.

> Specialization in Internet of Things (IoT)

For which position are you applying? It's unclear from the resume.

> Experience

XYZ is completely and irreversibly violated, check the recommendations in the chat pins.

> PayMax

It is worth adding a link to the project page. Google finds nothing related to the project by the provided name except for some Chinese payment service.
Also, the bullet points in the description are vague, with some being useless (e.g., the last 2 points).

> Technical Skills

Listing IDEs can be somewhat debatable, especially if you have to code in some Eclipse, where 90% is "I am the master, myself." Besides, databases, deployment tools, test frameworks, and a lot that you definitely used are not mentioned.

> Certifications

Cisco provides links for certificate verification, which would be worth adding to the CV. Furthermore, it might be better to remove SoftServe certifications, as they look inferior against Cisco, and merge the remaining 2 sections into one under the name. The presence of deadlines next to certificates also seems somewhat strange.

Does IT Step issue a bachelor's diploma? I thought it was just courses, and I have heard very bad reviews about them.
What market are you applying to? There's a different layout/content for resumes in the US.

It’s lengthy, even quite so. I think it can be shortened. Also, the statement about "trying to contribute to open-source" doesn’t look great at first glance, especially considering your GitHub activity shows that all the PRs in the last 12+ months are exclusively in the educational repositories of Mate Academy and not in any popular well-known libraries like React, which makes the open-source contribution a bit weak if they are educational repositories and tasks. The relevance of this mention is up to your discretion.

> experience
>> •Increased the number of unit tests from 3,688 to 4,104 to reduce the number of customer-reported bugs (I was really tired of dealing with them)

XYZ rule is violated in places (a reference mentioned).

> •Increased crash-free users rate from 87.6% to 94.2%

Wait, was your app crashing for about every tenth user, and now it’s for every twentieth? It doesn’t look good when most aim for a higher percentage after 99%. Better expand that bullet point into something like that. This way, you'll avoid a surprised question about the app's low reliability.

> Goji Labs: 04/2020 - 06/2022,
> Focus..: 02/2019 - 05/2020

Double employment isn’t necessarily a good thing; in my opinion, it’s better to change it to (or 04/2020, it depends on preference).

> •Integrated facebook/apple/google authorization based on Firebase, 23.4% of users used this authorization within a month after release.
•Optimized the use of SSR and SSG in Next.js and separated all tasks as much as possible (client and server components), consequently increasing the CEO in the lighthouse.

Go through the entire resume, check the style and grammar. I’m sure a couple of abbreviations weren’t written in caps :)

> EDUCATION

How come? New cities?

You could split it into education and courses, turn the Odessa "Step" into (or 2021 - 2025), and list the other two under courses.

Does IT Step issue a bachelor's diploma? I thought it was just courses, and I have heard very bad reviews about them.
What market are you applying to? There's a different layout/content for resumes in the US.

> about

It’s lengthy, even quite so. I think it can be shortened. Also, the statement about "trying to contribute to open-source" doesn’t look great at first glance, especially considering your GitHub activity shows that all the PRs in the last 12+ months are exclusively in the educational repositories of Mate Academy and not in any popular well-known libraries like React, which makes the open-source contribution a bit weak if they are educational repositories and tasks. The relevance of this mention is up to your discretion.

> experience
>> •Increased the number of unit tests from 3,688 to 4,104 to reduce the number of customer-reported bugs (I was really tired of dealing with them)

XYZ rule is violated in places (a reference mentioned).

> •Increased crash-free users rate from 87.6% to 94.2%

Wait, was your app crashing for about every tenth user, and now it’s for every twentieth? It doesn’t look good when most aim for a higher percentage after 99%. Better expand that bullet point into something like that. This way, you'll avoid a surprised question about the app's low reliability.

> Goji Labs: 04/2020 - 06/2022,
> Focus..: 02/2019 - 05/2020

Double employment isn’t necessarily a good thing; in my opinion, it’s better to change it to (or 04/2020, it depends on preference).

> •Integrated facebook/apple/google authorization based on Firebase, 23.4% of users used this authorization within a month after release.
•Optimized the use of SSR and SSG in Next.js and separated all tasks as much as possible (client and server components), consequently increasing the CEO in the lighthouse.

Go through the entire resume, check the style and grammar. I’m sure a couple of abbreviations weren’t written in caps :)

> EDUCATION

How come? New cities?

You could split it into education and courses, turn the Odessa "Step" into (or 2021 - 2025), and list the other two under courses.

It does, but they also have regular courses, and concerning reviews, it’s a contentious topic—some like it and it’s all fine, while others may not be satisfied, but those who want to will always seek information, learn, and not spend time writing reviews, this is my opinion.
It used to be fine before.

You're an AI agent who specializes on CV reviews and scoring. You'll be provided with a CV in yaml format and your task is to provide a review of the CV.
You should answer as if you were a hiring manager / team lead who reviews the CVs
Your task is to review a resume and find the weaknesses of the resume

## Review format
Output 4 to 7 sentences with your verdict.
Focus on the weak spots rather than strengths. 
You should be dull and honest, and skeptical. 
You should suggest converting most of the statements into XYZ form.
However, whenever you criticise anything, you must also provide a comment what how the thing can be improved.
Example:
```
If the user has in the resume something like that:
"I implemented a new subscription model with stripe API. We used to use hard-coded links, but now we configure it on the fly in our parametric model."
You should answer that this format is not the best-selling one and should rather be converted to the following style:
"Implemented a dynamic subscription model using Stripe API, replacing hard-coded links with a parametric configuration, resulting in a more scalable and flexible payment system."
```
Your task is to criticise the CV and suggest the improvements.

> programming languages

Kotlin/Swift is missing to tick all checkboxes :) Also, no one writes "proficient/medium" in programming languages; there are special certificates for that.

> experience

Typically, there are 2-3 bullet points per position, focusing on achievements (80% of yours is "I did this and that"; where achievements are mentioned, they are hidden somewhere at the end). It needs to be rewritten with achievements in the forefront. Also, the XYZ rule has been violated (explanations in chat pins).

>> demonstrator

Is this something local? Judging by the position, it sounds like a standard TA/Teaching Assistant role. Considering you’re applying to Wise, maybe remove this section and add your pet projects instead?

> skills
>> databases

This is vague; it’s better to list specifics.

>> Devtools

IDE-wise, it's better to remove it, and scatter Docker/Postman and what remains across bullet points... 

>> Test and Libraries

Testing tools separately - maybe in the frontend (it’s definitely "material" not "materila"?). This is vague, and should also be removed.

I would be glad to receive feedback on the content)

> Developed Java 17 features for an Eclipse-based Intellij IDE

A typo (or if you wanted to anonymize the resume, then it didn't work out very well)

> Maintained Intellij by monitoring, developing, and refactoring automated tests 

You definitely didn't do this solo, so I recommend rewriting the bullets with specific results so that the results themselves are at the very beginning - the first 5-10 words. 

All other bullets of the form "did this and that, did that" (where there are no metrics) need to be deleted. And according to the standard, 2-3 bullets per position. 

Similarly, rework the bullets for the software engineer.

> reducing response time by a factor of 10, from an unacceptably slow 2000 ms to 200ms

This is sophistry ("unacceptable"), it's better to remove adjectives of that sort from the bullets completely.

> education
>> Safety-Performance Trade-offs in Aligned Large Language Models

If you're not applying to companies where LLMs are a must-have - you can remove it. Optionally - add a link to the PDF of the diploma (if the university has posted it). 

===

Overall, it looks solid, even if you get hired, but maybe add a couple of pet projects?
